loans.name: Lil Joy

texts.en:
Lil Joy V. is from the village of Culing Centro, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 46 years old and married with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lil Joy sells frozen chicken, pork, and fish in the local community. Lil Joy has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month. In 2007, Lil Joy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lil Joy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50000 PHP from ASKI and now requests her 8th loan, for 50000 PHP, to buy more products to sell.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy chicken, pork, and fish to sell.

loans.name: Costa

texts.en:
Costa K. is married and has seven children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of some of her in-laws. Costa lives in a home that she owns in the Kawempe neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent for her business premises.

Costa recently changed her business enterprise from frying samosas and chapatti to selling cereals. She has been in this business for a few months, and she works six days a week. Costa sells her products wholesale at the market. She also generates additional income by renting rooms. The main business challenges for Costa include transportation and seasonality.

Costa has requested a loan of 1,000,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of cowpeas. Her goal for her business is to start going directly to farmers for cowpeas and also to own a delivery van.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cowpeas

loans.name: Aropat's Group

texts.en:
Aropat T. is the leader of this group. She is 51, married and has raised three sons; two sons work in construction and the third son went to work in Russia. Her husband is handicapped, so she takes care of him. In order to make money Aropat breeds livestock. With money received from the loan Aropat wants to purchase sheep for breeding and then resell them at a higher price after fattening them.

Munishon D. is the treasurer of the group. She is 45, married and has raised two sons and a daughter. The first son is a farmer, the second works in Russia and the daughter is married and lives separately with her family. Sixteen years ago when the collective farms broke up, Munishon got a piece of land. Since that time she and her husband have cultivated different fruits and vegetables. Her husband sells the harvest at the market, making 3000 KGS per month. Munishon applied for a loan because she wants to buy another piece of land for farming. In the future she wants to purchase a vehicle.

Maripathon B. is 46, married and has a daughter and two sons. In order to make money her sons and husband work in construction. Maripathon farms; she cultivates fruits and vegetables. With money received from a loan she wants to hire labor for the sowing process. In the future she plans to start repairing the house and purchase a cow for breeding.

Mukumjon S. is 38, married and has a son and two daughters, all of whom are at school. Mukumjon and his wife are farmers; they cultivate cotton. By selling the cotton they make 5000 KGS a month. With money received from a loan Mukumjon wants to rent a piece of land and hire labor to sow the cotton seed.

About Mol Bulak Finance:

This loan is being presented by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of its “3-Ps” concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow larger) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep, buy and rent land, and hire laborers

loans.name: Hout

texts.en:
Hout H. was born in 1959 and has established a small family in the best part of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She stays at home taking care of daily duties. The family is supported by Hout’s husband who owns a motorcycle that he uses to provide a taxi service. They also receive help from her daughter who is employed in Malaysia.

Hout’s husband’s motorcycle is old and often breaks down, resulting in a decline in income. Hout hopes to resolve this problem by obtaining a loan for her husband to replace his broken taxi.

loans.use: To replace her husband's broken motorcycle

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer is a 54-year-old married lady with six children. She has eight dependants and lives in a rented house. She operates a clothing shop in which she also does her tailoring business. She has been in the business for seven years and says so far it has been good for her in the venture. She actually hopes to see her business move to greater heights. This is her seventh loan from HOFOKAM and she intends to purchase clothes, thread and yarn for her clothing business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes, thread and yarn for her clothing business

loans.name: Zubaida

texts.en:
Zubaida lives in the historic city of Pakistan, called Lahore. She operates a clothing sales business. She buys the clothes from Anarkali and Azam cloth market, which are famous wholesale cloth markets in Lahore, and sells in her local area to earn an income.  

She is married to M. I., a security guard by profession. She is the mother of 4 sons and 2 daughters. She couldn’t educate them all, except for her two elder sons, who also left their education due to financial constraints. They now work as salesmen in a big grocery store. Zubaida and her family live in a 3 room house in the area of Shalimar town, located near Shalimar gardens.  

Zubaida has applied for a loan from Asasah for her clothes-selling business. She will utilize the loan amount to buy clothes in bulk. This will allow her to offer a variety to her clients. She hopes that she will increase her sales and, simultaneously, her income. She is a new loan user of Asasah. She hopes it will be a good experience for her.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothes-selling business.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. lives in Kawempe neighborhood, in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (sisters). Margaret has a business of selling ground nuts, both squeezed and cereals. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Margaret sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale and retail.    

Margret has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bags of ground nuts. She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenge(s) for Margaret include transportation and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van. Margaret lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent for her business premises.

loans.use: To buy more bags of groundnuts.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea L., 56 years old, owns a medium-sized stone house where she lives and operates a café business. She is a single mother and has three children. Two of her children are already married and have started new homes. The other one, a single son, appears on the photograph above. Chea L. receives help for her responsibilities from her son who is a car detailer in a private garage. 

Chea L. is concerned that her income is not very much as her business has recently suffered due to insufficient financial capital. Chea L. wishes to have more funds to increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to look for lenders on Kiva.

loans.use: To increase her capital.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella C. is from the village of Culing Centro, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 49 years old. Estrella is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Estrella owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling used clothing in the local community. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Estrella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Estrella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is the father of two young children. He has more than 20 years of experience running a small car repair shop. He is especially talented in car electricity repair. He also works on a freelance basis with some car repair shops who ask for his electrical services.  Today he is requesting a loan of $700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.al. to purchase new tools for his business. In the future, he is looking to diversify his business and open a new shop where he can buy and sell car spare parts. His income is needed to help support his wife and two children and to pay the schooling fees.

loans.use: To purchase new tools for his business

loans.name: Gulzoda's Group

texts.en:
Gulzoda K. is the leader of this group. She is 45 and married. She has three sons: the first son works in Russia, the second is a construction worker and the youngest son is at school. Gulzoda works as a teacher at a school and her husband is a butcher. They also breed cattle and sell it, after fattening, at a higher price. In this way they make 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Gulzoda wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she wants to purchase a piece of land and start building a house for her son.

Muminahon T., 47, is married. She has two sons and a daughter. The son work in Russia and the daughter is at school. Her husband went to work in Russia too. Muminahon herself works as a teacher at school; she also breeds livestock. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase sheep in order to increase her number of livestock. In the future she plans to start repairing her house. 

Mohirahon M. is the treasurer of the group. She is 27 and divorced. She has a two year old daughter. In order to make money Mohirahon breeds livestock. She sells sheep each month, in this way she makes 2000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase sheep, in order to resell it at a higher price, after fattening. 

Ulduzhon A., 35, is married. She has a son and two daughters. The son and the first daughter are at school, and the second daughter is newborn.  Ulduzhon is a teacher at school and her husband works as a driver. They also breed livestock to make money. Selling some animals each month, they made 3000 soms. That profit made it possible for them to save money and to build a shed. With money received from the loan, Ulduzhon wants to purchase sheep for breeding. In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education, to purchase a piece of land and build a house for her son.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Wilson's Group

texts.en:
Wilson C., from the village of San Roque, is the 37-year-old group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Wilson C.'s Group.

Wilson, who is married and has two school-aged children, owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Wilson joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase new items to expand product offering, she is now requesting a new loan, her fifth, of 17000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Wilson plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda S. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood, in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (relatives).

Sauda has a business of a  hair salon. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Sauda sells her products from home, by means of retail. Sauda has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of cosmetic, cream hair relaxers and braids. The main business challenge(s) for Sauda include seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to expand her current business and to own a bridal salon. Sauda lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cosmetics, cream hair relaxers and braids.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 49-year-old married woman from Lebanon. A mother of four children, she has established a sewing business from her home. She has more than 20 years' experience as a talented seamstress. She produces all type of clothes according to the customer’s request. Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase tailoring supplies and textiles to offer a variety of products to her clientele. Her services are valued by customers in some of Lebanon’s suburban towns.  In the future, she is expecting to continue expansion of her business to earn more income and continue the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase tailoring supplies and textiles

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo P. is from the village of Culing Centro, Cabatuan, Isabela. He is 42 years old. Alfredo is single. To make a living, Alfredo owns & operates a business providing motorcycle transport to local community members. Alfredo has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month in these activity.

In 2007, Alfredo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Alfredo has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Alfredo is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will again be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Alfredo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business.

loans.name: Shagufta's Group

texts.en:
Shagufta lives in a small city in Pakistan called Chichawatni, which is famous for its agricultural industry. She is a 56 year old lady who has been living in a three-roomed brick house with her family in Chichawatni for 25 years. She is married to M. Y.,  a fruit seller, and has 2 sons, both of them are illiterate and work. Her elder son has a fruit shop and her younger son works in a gas station. 

Shagufta has applied for a loan from Asasah for her elder son’s business. With the loan amount he will buy seasonal fruits to sell to his clients. Shagufta hopes that her son will be able to increase his income by increasing his inventory of fruit. He has 10 years of experience in this business. Previously, he was working with her father but 5 years ago he started his business separately. 

Shagufta is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 4th loan cycle. In her previous loan years, she proved herself as a responsible client who never missed a single meeting and paid installments on time. 

In the picture, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hand is Shagufta.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits for fruit selling business.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 37-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has 20 years of experience working as a hairdresser. In 1995, he opened a barber shop in his town. Over the years, he has been able to gain a good number of clients and he is thankful for his business income. 

He took advantage of a first loan from Kiva, and he was a very reliable client with his repayments. Today, he is asking for a second loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to renew his tools and purchase a new hairdressing machine in order to expand his business.

In the future, he hopes to open another barber shop branch and extend his business into other areas.

loans.use: To renew his tools and purchase a new hairdressing machine

loans.name: Gulbar

texts.en:
Gulbar A. is the resident of Balykchi, a nice city in Isykul region. Gulbar is 44 years old and she is married. She has two daughters and two sons, the first daughter and the first son study at university, the second daughter is at school and the second son is preschool age (under seven). Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Gulbar started to sell cookies at the market, and then she saved some money, rented a pavilion and began to sell toys and children’s clothes. In this way she makes 15000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase a vehicle. She also pays for her children’s education at university. Gulbar is applying for a loan because she needs money to purchase more toys and clothes in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to expand her business and open her own store.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase toys.

loans.name: Kuluipa

texts.en:
Kuluipa T. is the resident of Balykchi, a nice city in Isykul region. Kuluipa is 43 years old and she is married. She has a son and a daughter, both of them are at school. Fifteen years ago, with the initial investment of 15000 soms, Kuluipa started to purchase dishes in Bishkek and then resell them at a higher price in Balykchi. In this way, she makes 25000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase a house. 

With money received from this loan she wants to purchase more dishes in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education and to save money to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase dishes.

loans.name: Uulkan

texts.en: Uulkan T. is a resident of Balykchi, a nice city in the Isykul region. Uulkan is 50 and married. She has raised two sons and two daughters. The first daughter is married and lives separately with her family, and the second works as a bookkeeper. The first son works in a computer store, and the second son is a student. Uulkan works as a dentist and her husband makes money by transporting coal. Six years ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 soms, Uulkan purchased equipment and began to provide dental services. In this way, she earns 25,000 soms per month. She applied for this loan because her husband needs money to purchase coal in order to resell it at a higher price in winter. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase coal

loans.name: Gladys  Wambui

texts.en:
Gladys Wambui, a 37 year old lady, runs a salon in Mwimto. She is married to Peter Kamau, who is 40 years old and is a businessman. Gladys has been in this business for 15 years and is capable of making a profit of KES120,000 per month. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and she is applying for her third loan of KES73,000 with KADET LTD, after paying her previous loans successfully.

With this loan she plans to buy more inventory of cosmetics and also to buy another hair dryer to help serve her clients better. The business is in a busy place where her clients are served well, due to the availability of cosmetics that she able to get at retail prices, and sell them directly to her customers. With the extra income she plans to pay back her loan and to expand her business.

In the future, Gladys hopes to operate a hairdressing and beauty college in Mwimto where she will be to capture the attention of many young generations that havw interest in learning hairdressing. She believes that this will certainly expand her business and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more inventory of cosmetics and another hair dryer to help serve her clients better.

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima B. is the resident of Balykchi, a nice city in Isykul region. Alima is 43 years old and she is married. She has three sons and a daughter, two older sons study at university and the other children are preschool age (under seven). Six years ago, with the initial investment of 40000 soms, Alima started to sell dishes and home products at the market. In this business, she makes 15000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to pay for her son’s education at university. She also saved money and purchased a vehicle.  With money received from this loan, Alima wants to purchase a pavilion and with some part of the loan, she will purchase more dishes to increase the turnover of her business. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a pavilion.

loans.name: God Grace Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Grace. He is 32 years old, married, and has two children who are between the ages of five and ten years old. He was only able to attend school through eleventh grade, due to financial constraints.
 
For seven years, he has been selling copy books on Pipeline Road Market in Paynesville, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 27,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more dozens of copy books. He describes himself as a hard-working man whose goals are to improve his business and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more dozens of copy books.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new computer

loans.name: Dy

texts.en:
Mr. Dy S., 58, is a general doctor who works in the community hospital. He owns a small clinic in his home where he sells medicine and examines patients who live nearby. Married to Teng Khorn, a 42-year-old who assists him in selling medicine, they are blessed with one young child who is enrolled in school. 

Dy S. faces difficulty traveling to work or anywhere else because he doesn’t have his own vehicle for transportation needs. As he lacks money to buy one, Dy S. decided to request a loan of US$1,200 to be used to purchase a new motorcycle. With the remainder of the loan, he will meet some of the requirements for his clinic.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Asankadir

texts.en:
Asankadir K. is 53-year-old farmer who lives in At-Bashy village, in the north of Kyrgyzstan. He is married and has six children. His spouse is a housewife who keeps their hearth and home in harmony.  

Asankadir worked as a driver at the local combine complex and retired on a pension. But, his pension and his wife's pension, combined, doesn't meet their household expenses. They decided to engage in cattle breeding to make extra income. Asankadir used his initial capital of 10,000 KGS to buy livestock and managed to multiply its number. In order to broaden his business, he applied to Bai-Tushum and Partners for his first loan and repaid it without any delays.  

For the further enlargement of his business, Asankadir plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to buy one horse and sheep. With the revenues, he plans to renovate his barn in order to provide good conditions for cattle maintenance. Also, in the future, Asankadir dreams to buy a minivan and return to his favorite transportation work activity. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Mrs. Pen S., 26, is a mother who is caring for one child. She runs a small wooden store in front of her house, where she sells little snack foods and some groceries to her neighbors in the village. She is married to Sopheak, 29, who is a local goldsmith and also a porter in the busy local market. Pen S. is taking out her loan to accumulate a quantity of grocery inventory to sell. She intends to use some of the money to repair her motor that often breaks down.

loans.use: To accumulate grocery inventory to sell

loans.name: Papa God Group

texts.en:
George J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Papa God. He is 35 years old, single and has three children whose ages are between six months and twelve years. He was only able to attend school through twelve grade due to financial constraints. 

For two years, George has been operating a foreign exchange bureau in the Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 14,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 64,000 LRD group loan to add more money to his business. He describes himself as a devoted man whose goals are to improve his business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Harris is inset at the lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To add more money to his business

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida N. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood, in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has six children, one of whom is in school. She also takes care of her mother. Hamida lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but doesn't have piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication and school fees.

Hamida has a business selling bananas. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Hamida sells her products at the market. 

Hamida has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas. The main business challenges for Hamida include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of bananas. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going directly to farmers for bananas.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, fish, meat and some sacs of water

loans.name: Women Together #2 Group

texts.en:
Marie T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Women Together #2". She is 39 years old, single and has three children whose ages are between 9 and 16 years. She was only able to attend school through tenth grade due to lack of financial support.

For four years, she has been manufacturing and selling “iron soap”, a locally manufactured soap made from caustic and red oil, in the Red Light market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 45,000 LRD group loan to buy more gallons of caustic and red oil. She describes herself as a jovial woman whose goals are to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of caustic and red oil

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of flour and some cloth

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. lives in the Lungujja neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. Annet sells firewood. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days out of every week. Annet sells her products retail from home. She lives in a home that she owns. She doesn't have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

Annet has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bundles of firewood. The main business challenge for Annet is transportation. Her goals and aspirations are to improve her standard of living and also to own a delivery van.

loans.use: To buy more bundles of firewood

loans.name: Mother’S Blessing Group

texts.en:
Esther B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Mother’s Blessing". She is 37 years old, married and has four children whose ages are between 3 and 20. She was only able to attend school through fifth grade due to lack of financial support. 

For five years, she has been operating a mini restaurant in the Red Light market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 40,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of rice, fish, meat, pepper, salt, etc. She describes herself as a friendly woman whose goals are to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, fish, meat, pepper, salt, etc.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace N. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, none of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Grace has a restaurant. She has been in this business for over ten years, and she works seven days out of every week. Grace sells her products wholesale from home. Grace lives in a home that she rents. She doesn't have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and medication. 

Grace has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy rice, maize flour and bananas. The main business challenges for Grace include increasing prices of food and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations are to see her business grow big and to own a fully stocked hotel (restaurant). She decided to join MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting additional capital.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like rice, maize flour and bunches of bananas

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: God Will Provide Group

texts.en:
Korto F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Will Provide.  She is 28 years old, married, and has three children whose ages are between two weeks and ten years. She was only able to attend school through tenth grade due to a lack of financial support. 

For three years, she has been selling cold water and soft drinks in “Red Light Market” on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 60,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more crates of soft drinks and sacks of water. 

She describes herself as a determined woman whose dream is to improve her business and to continue to pursue her education so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and sacks of water for sale

loans.name: Line

texts.en: Line N. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school.   She also takes care of additional family members (relatives). Line has a business of dry cleaning. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days every week. Line works from her home, by means of retail. Line has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy another flat iron, powdered soap and boxes of bar soap for her business. The main business challenge for Line is seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to expand her business so that she can employ two girls to assist her in washing clothes. She decided to join MCDT because she wanted additional capital. Line lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy another flat iron, powdered soap and boxes of bar soap

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy frozen meat and pork for sale

loans.name: Pauline Achieng

texts.en:
Pauline is a 29 year old lady married to Paul jura, who sells spare parts of motor vehicles in Kisumu. He supports the family by paying the rent and school fees, and purchasing food. They have two children aged six years and four years. Pauline runs E.C.D. Nursery school in Kisumu. She has been in this business for two years and receives an income of Kshs. 9,000 per month.

She learned about KADET LTD through a friend, who is also client of KADET. She is applying for her first loan of Kshs.10,000 with KADET to buy desks and cement for the floor of the school. She plans to use business profit to pay back the loan, and also to grow the business.

Pauline plans to have a stable school for all levels of education that will enable financial sustainability.

loans.use: To buy desks and cement for the floor

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cloth for his business

loans.name: Kimbat

texts.en:
Kimbat P. is a single mother of two daughters.  She graduated from Trade college and worked as an accountant for four years. As it was very hard to bring up the children by herself on a low wage, Kimbat decided to start her own business in trade. 

Starting in 2007, she managed to broaden her business by renting a small shop and achieving success. Her loyal customers were attracted by her careful attitude and cheerfulness. 

But in June 2010, violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the city of Osh. Kimbat lost her business, which was burned to ashes.

Kimbat doesn’t give up, however, and she is ready to resume her lost business and to continue to work. That is why Kimbat is applying for a loan of 100,000 KGS, which she needs to restart her activity. She plans to rent a selling point at the local market to sell womens clothing. 

Kimbat is a very optimistic person who believes that giving a small chance to another person can inspire them for a great future.  

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for retail

loans.name: Zamiri Group

texts.fr: Mauwa M. est  présidente  groupe Zamiri, âgée de 38 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants, son mari est  gardien. Son fils ainé a 17 ans et le cadet a 3 ans et tous étudient, sauf le cadet.  Il y a 17 ans qu’elle exerce le petit commerce général. Elle a commence avec ses fonds propre reçu de son mari environ 100$. Elle vend de sucre, Omo, riz, etc.  Elle expose ses marchandises dans le marché central de Virunga. Ce crédit va lui permettre d’augmenter  son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  10 sacs de Riz, 5 sacs d’Omo, etc. Le grand obstacle est  qu’elle vend en monnaie nationale (franc congolais). Cependant cette monnaie congolaise n’est pas stable, elle subit de plus à plus l’inflation, ce qui entraine de perte de change avec la devise (les dollars), comme tous les congolais craignent le franc congolais, pour garder leurs économies en dollars. Elle souhaite acheter une parcelle pour ses enfants et y construire. La cliente Mauwa M. remercie  Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres citoyens exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Zamiri est composé de 15 membres.
texts.en:
Mauwa M. is the president of the Zamiri Group. She is 38 years old, has eight children, and her husband is a security guard. Her eldest son is 17 years old, the youngest is three, and all but the youngest are in school. She has been running her business for 17 years. She began with about $100 that she received from her husband. She sells sugar, Omo soap, rice, etc. She displays her merchandise in the central market of Virunga. This loan will allow her to increase her turnover by purchasing ten bags of rice, five bags of Omo soap, etc. The biggest challenge is that she sells in the national currency (Congolese francs). Because this Congolese currency is not stable, she is subjected to more and more inflation, which leads to a loss in exchange with foreign currency (dollars). She is like many Congolese who fear the Congolese franc and instead keep their savings in dollars. She would like to buy a small plot of land on which to build for her children. As a client, Mauwa M. thanks Hekima for its actions to help the poor citizens who are excluded from traditional banks. One should note that the Zamiri Group has 15 members.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is 48 years old and married to a poultry farmer.  The couple has four children who are in school.  Previously a shopkeeper, Samuel runs a supermarket to earn his daily bread and also rents out houses to supplement his family’s income.  He is a registered member of New Pambazuko group in Faulu Kenya and has been guaranteed a loan of 60,000 Kes which he will use to increase his stock of sugar, cooking fat, maize flour and soap.  Samuel  hopes to increase the number of his rental houses in the future.

loans.use: To increase his stock of sugar, cooking fat, maize flour and soap

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: Wilson, who is 40 years old, married and the father of one child, operates a cafeteria as well as a key cutting business.  A hardworking man, he is also an electrician.  In his business, Wilson employs two people. He is now requesting a loan of 60,000 Kes to buy a gas cooker and a refrigerator.  He hopes to build flats in the future so as to improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a gas cooker and a refrigerator

loans.name: Muriuki

texts.en: Muriuki is a married man with three children named Charles (15), Nicholas (10) and David (4). To make a living, he has been operating Quality G. shop, where he employs two people. He also runs a grocery shop for extra income. He was previously operating a cafeteria. He belongs to Maona self help group of Faulu Kenya. Through the group, he has requested 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy gas cylinders and add stock of sugar, cooking fat, rice and flour. He hopes to transform his retail shop into a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To buy gas cylinders and add stock of sugar, cooking fat, rice and flour

loans.name: Norman

texts.en: Norman is a 24-year-old member of Unique 09 group of Faulu Kenya. He supplies bread and cakes in Kayole town in Nairobi East. His business is located in a very competitive environment. He supplies cakes and bread to shops, schools and hospitals. He also works as a housing agent to boost his income. Norman has been in business for three years. He has managed to expand his business and has become one of the major suppliers of cakes and bread. He hopes to expand his business to other territories in the future. He has requested 80,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase a motorbike for transporting his products.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Mujeres Alegres Group

texts.es:
Descripción:	Las mujeres del presente comité son del barrio Costa Alegre de la compañía cabañas de la cuidad de Caacupé. 
Son muy trabajadoras y unidas, realizan actividades diversas como grupo, así pueden adelantar el pago de sus cuotas y acceder a un crédito mayor en un corto plazo. 
Las Señoras están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya, porque gracias a la institución pueden acceder a créditos con facilidad, también a constantes capacitaciones, ahora también capacitaciones para con sus hijos, con el programa de aflatoun; con eso enriquecen sus conocimientos y ayudan al sustento de sus hogares.
Las integrantes ya culminaron hoy su ciclo crediticio número 14, poseen una antigüedad de  4 años aproximadamente.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Florentina R. quien es costurera de ropas para damas y caballero.
Ella se dedica a esta actividad hace buen tiempo y tiene muchos clientes que acuden a ella ya les gusta su trabajo.
Con esta actividad puede ayudar a su familia y mediante el comité ella se capacita y mejora su trabajo y al mismo tiempo utiliza y administra mejor los recursos con que cuenta.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de telas, hilos, cierres, botones, y otros accesorios que ella utiliza para su confeccion.
texts.en:
The women of this group are from the “Costa Alegre de la compañía cabañas” neighborhood of the city of Caacupé. They are hardworking and united ladies, each working different activities as part of the group. In this way they are able to get ahead on their payments and pay off large loans in a short time. The ladies are very grateful to Fundación Paraguaya, because, thanks to this institution, they are able get their loans easily. It also provides them with constant learning, for them and their children, through the “Aflatoun” program. This way they are able to enrich their knowledge and help them maintain their households. The members have completed their 14th loan cycle and have been in the program for approximately four years. One of the members is Florentina R., who is a seamstress and makes ladies’ and men’s clothing. She’s been doing this for a good amount of time and has lots of customers who patronize her, because they like her work. She’s able to help her family through this business; and through the group she can better her skills, improve her work, and at the same time better manage her resources through her account. She is asking for this loan in order to buy fabrics, thread, fasteners, buttons, and other accessories that she uses for her creations.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Pravin

texts.en: Pravin is 27 years old and married.  For two years, he has been running a retail shop.  He sells sugar, rice, maize flour, soap and tea leaves in his shop.  He also sells water to earn extra income.  Being a member of Faulu Kenya, he has learnt how to save his money.  He has requested 40,000 Kenyan shillings to increase his stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, soap and tea leaves.

loans.use: To increase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, soap and tea leaves

loans.name: Moureen

texts.en: Moureen is 23 years old and married.  She is a member of Jobowisa self help group of Faulu Kenya.  Since 2006, she has been running a salon and a cafeteria in a busy and populated environment.  She employs one person in her business.  She has requested 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy bags of flakes. She hopes to open up other branches for her business in the future.

loans.use: To buy bags of flakes

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 52 years old.  He is a hardworking businessman who runs a series of businesses like a butcher shop and cafeteria, and he sells furniture.  He also rents out houses.  He has been in business for twelve years.  He has requested 60,000 Kenyan shillings through Harmony group of Faulu Kenya.  With the loan, he wants to buy shares in one of the Kenyan banks.  He hopes to own an estate in the future.

loans.use: To buy shares in a bank

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is a member of Jobiswa group of Faulu Kenya.  He is 30 years old and has been selling clothes for two years.  Apart from selling clothes, he runs a cafeteria.  He has previously serviced a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Faulu Kenya.  He is requesting another loan of 50,000 KES to buy clothes.  He hopes to build flats in the future.  Daniel is the father of one child.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a 49-year-old single mother of four.  It's five years since she started running Mary's Boutique where she sells clothes and shoes.  Most of her customers are women.  She employs one person and she hopes to expand the business.  She has requested 40,000 Kenyan shillings to add to her stock of clothes and shoes.  For this loan, she has been guaranteed by the Pamoja group of Faulu Kenya, of which she is a member.  In ten years, she wants to operate her business in Nairobi city centre.  She describes herself as hardworking and faithful.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes and shoes

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is married to a driver. She is blessed with three children. She has been selling scrap metal for one year. She sells the scrap metal to industries for recycling. She is a member of Baraka Ukweli group of Faulu Kenya. She wants to take out a first loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to increase her stock of scrap metal. She hopes to provide a good education for her children. She describes herself as hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: To add stock of scrap metals

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is 33 years old and married. To earn a living, she sells bed sheets, bed covers and scarfs. She has been in the business for two years. She was previously running a grocery shop. She is a member of Upendo Imara group of Faulu Kenya. She has acquired business knowledge and joined the savings culture. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy bed sheets, bed covers and curtains. She hopes to own a permanent business premises in the future.

loans.use: To buy bed sheets, bedcovers and curtains

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is a 39-year-old married lady.  She owns a retail shop where she sells sugar, wheat and maize flour, rice and soap.  She was previously operating a grocery shop.  It's been one year now since she started her retail shop.  She has been able to save her money since she joined Faulu Kenya.  She hopes to increase her business stock. She has requested 35,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sugar, maize flour, rice and soap.  In five years, she wants to build rental houses.

loans.use: To increase stock of sugar, maize flour, rice and soap

loans.name: Costa Pucú Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son de la compañía Costa Pucú de la cuidad de Caacupé. 
Son muy trabajadoras, muy organizadas y unidas, mantienen un buen sentido de pertenencia grupal; eso les favorece a la hora de la renovación del crédito, pues no teniendo días de atrasos pueden aumentar sus montos y pasar de ciclo. 
Las Señoras están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya, porque gracias a los beneficios que les ofrecen, tanto con los créditos como también con las constantes capacitaciones que reciben, encontraron la forma de ayudar al sustento de sus hogares.
Las integrantes ya culminaron hoy su ciclo crediticio número 4, poseen una antigüedad de 1 año 4 meses aproximadamente. 
Entre la integrantes se encuentra la señora
 Pablina, una mujer muy activa y trabajadora que lucha todos los días para sacar delante de la mejor manera a su familia. 
Ella tiene como actividad de costurera, hace de todo en cuanto a costura se refiera como confección de ropas, cortes de sabanas, fundas, ropas para niños, y otros. 
Además de esa actividad para el consumo de la familia ella cuenta con animales, lo que también le da mucho trabajo. 
Pero ella se siente muy bien trabajando y ayudando a su familia y desea mucho seguir haciéndolo. 
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de materiales que ella utiliza para su confección.
texts.en:
The women of this group are from the Costa Pucú company, located in the city of Caacupé. They are hardworking, very organized, united, and maintain a good group identity. This helps them at loan renewal time. By not falling behind, they are able to increase their amounts and complete the cycle. The women are very grateful to Fundación Paraguaya because, thanks to the benefits and training that they receive, the have found a way to sustain their households. These members have completed their fourth cycle and have been in the program for approximately one year and four months. Pablina is among the members and is a very active, hard working woman who struggles daily to get her family ahead as best she can. She is a seamstress who makes clothing, sheets, bedspreads, clothing for children, and other things. She also raises animals for food, which is also hard work. She feels comfortable working and helping her family and would very much like to continue. She is asking for this loan in order to buy supplies that she needs for her work as a seamstress.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en: Ludmila is married with one teenage son. She sells children's clothing at Ilona Market in Mukachevo town. She's been in this business for 16 years. Long experience and great optimism help Ludmila to maintain good sales. Moreover, children's clothing is always in demand. Ludmila would like to purchase more school clothing for sale. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 grivnas. Ludmila has good relationships with her colleagues at the market. They support and encourage one another to overcome difficult economic or personal challenges.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Cosmas

texts.en: Cosmas is 26 years old and married to a teacher. He is blessed with one child. He offers transport using his handcart (mkokoteni). He also does farming to get extra cash. Being a businessman, he joined Pamoja group of Faulu Kenya where he saves his money. He has been guaranteed a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings by the group. With the loan, he will buy five handcarts. He hopes to buy a canter in the future so as to improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy five handcarts

loans.name: Ramon

texts.es:
El señor Ramón de 50 años de edad, reside en el cantón piedra azul, de San Rafael Oriente San Miguel,el es un agricultor, está casado y vive con su esposa y tres hijos de las edades 22, 12 y 8 años quienes dependen económicamente de él. Don Ramón aprendió a cultivar el maíz por su padre que desde pequeño le enseño a sembrar la tierra, y desde entonces él lo tomo como el oficio principal para mantener a su familia, ya que lo realiza todos los años.
Él solicita un crédito que lo invertirá en la compra de abono para su siembra de maíz, la obtención de este crédito le ayudara a don Ramón a tener una mejor cosecha y una mayor producción para la alimentación de su familia.
Sus aspiraciones son seguir cultivando el maíz para poder obtener ingresos que le ayuden a cubrir los gastos de su hogar y poder darle a sus hijos la educación que necesitan para salir adelante, mejorando su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Ramon, 50 years of age, resides in the Piedra Azul (Blue Stone) canton in San Rafael Oriente, San Miguel. He is a farmer, married, and lives with his wife and 3 children, ages 22, 12 and 8, who are economically dependent upon him. Ramon learned to cultivate corn from his father who taught him from the time he was small, to sow the earth. And since then, every year, Ramon has pursued this as his principal trade to maintain his family. He is requesting a loan to buy manure for his corn crop. The loan will help Ramon obtain a better harvest and greater production to feed his family. His aspirations are to continue cultivating corn in order to be able to obtain income that will help cover household expenses and give his children the education they need to get ahead, improving his quality of life and that of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING MANURE FOR HIS CORN CROP

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Arturo Ramon

texts.es:
El  Sr Arturo se dedica a la fabricación y ventas de colchones . Hace 3 años que se dedica a este rubro , ya que anteriormente trabajaba como operario en una empresa del mismo rubro , el es soltero y con un poco de su ahorro pudo montar su negocio  propio y así se   pudo independizar.
El  necesita invertir el crédito en la adquisición de un vehiculo  de mayor porte, para la distribución de sus productos, teniendo en cuenta que su actual vehículo ya le resulta pequeño para satisfacer las demandas. En el futuro  desea abrir su local propio.
texts.en:
Arturo makes and sells mattresses and has been doing this for three years. He used to work in a factory doing the same kind of work. He is single and he was able to start his own business with a bit of his savings. This allowed him to go out on his own. He needs this loan to invest in a large vehicle so that he can deliver his products. His current vehicle is too small to meet his needs. In the future he wants to open his own store.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle for business

loans.name: Pascual

texts.es:
El Sr. Pascual está casado, tiene una  hija en edad escolar.
 .
Él se dedica a la venta de comida rápida y de pescado en la zona de Ciudad del Este,  siendo un negocio de acceso a una clientela constante y formada, lo que colabora con que sea rentable. 

Es una persona destacada por su responsable conducta en cuanto al cumplimiento de sus obligaciones, tanto en el ámbito familiar como laboral. 

El préstamo al cual ha accedido le ha ayudado a crecer y desarrollarse un poco más en el ámbito de la microempresa.
texts.en:
Pascual is married and has a school-aged daughter. He sells fast food and seafood (fish) in the eastern zone of the city. Because his business has access to a constant and steady stream of customers, it is very profitable for him. He is known for his responsible behavior and reputation for meeting his obligations, both family and business. This loan has helped him grow and develop a bit as a small company.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Nelya

texts.en:
Nelya is single. She runs a small business selling jeans at Ilona Market in Mukachevo town. She has been in this business for five years. In the beginning she had to work as a sales person. Later she began to like and enjoy selling jeans. Nelya's business is quite successful because as fashion changes, women buy new jeans.

Nelya is very enthusiastic and positive about her life and her business. She wants to develop it further and increase turnover. Nelya needs a loan of 10,000 Grivnas to increase the assortment of winter jeans. She hopes to receive additional income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of jeans for sale.

loans.name: Elshad

texts.en:
Cattle farming is an economic activity dedicated to the raising of animals in order to generate revenue from the animals and the products they provide. Elshad H. has earned a living from raising cattle since he was young. He's married and has two children who, according to Elshad’s words, are his reason for living. It should be said that the low incomes available to people in this rural area aren't enough to maintain a family and, for this reason, Elshad works enormously hard to provide a better standard of living for his wife and children. 

Elshad urgently needs to buy animals such as cows and baby calves. He's applied for a loan of 1000 AZN.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and two baby calves.

loans.name: Esperanza Asegurada 1 Group

texts.en:
Berta is the coordinator of her group, Esperanza Asegurada 1 (Assured Hope). She makes her home in a simple structure with her two children. She says that her most difficult challenges are to build her house and to get her children educated.

Berta is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for two years, starting with selling girls underwear after she received her first loan with Esperanza. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying clothing like shirts, pants, underwear and mens t-shirts. She will use the profits to buy a better stove for her home and also to save to reach her dream come true, in which she has her own home built with a good structure.
 
This Esperanza associate began with us because she has more facilities and, with them, she can maintain her business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients in general (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti).  Her group is located in San Pedro de Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and the sugar cane industry.  The main economic activities are free trade and a cement factory. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: To buy clothes for re-sale.

loans.name: Raqif

texts.en: Raqif Q. is a successful entrepreneur and a dedicated husband. He began a small grocery store a year ago with a small amount of capital he had saved. He was assisted by his wife who helps him serve his clients. Today his clientele has grown and his grocery store has become more popular. His monthly income is 250-300 AZN. He is asking for a loan of 800 AZN so that he may expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store.

loans.use: to purchase more goods

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Don Mario es un agricultor de 52 años de edad, reside en el Cantón piedra Azul de San Rafael Oriente en San Miguel, está casado y vive con su esposa y tres hijos de 10, 14, 18 años de edad, su familia depende económicamente de él. Don Mario aprendió a sembrar maíz y frijol desde los 15 años de edad cuando su padre le enseñaba como lo debía hacer.
Él solicita un crédito el cual invertirá en la compra de abonos para poder cultivar maíz y frijol, este crédito le ayudara a obtener una mayor y mejor producción de maíz y frijol, que a su vez ayudara a cubrir las necesidades principales de su familia. Él sueña con seguir produciendo Maíz y Frijol y que dicha actividad le ayude a desarrollar a sus hijos con la educación que necesitan para poder seguir adelante mejorando cada día su condición económica.
texts.en:
Mario is a 52-year-old farmer. He lives in the small town of Piedra Azul de San Rafael Oriente in San Miguel. He's married and he lives with his wife and three children of 10, 14, and 18 years of age. His family depends on him economically. Mario learned to plant corn and beans 15 years ago when his father taught him how it was done. He's requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of fertilizers to cultivate corn and beans. This loan will help him achieve a better production of his crops, which will help cover he principle necessities of his family. His dream is to continue producing corn and beans and that this activity will help his children get the education necessary to get ahead and improve their economic condition.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer to plant corn and beans

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Telli

texts.en:
Telli B. is 55 years old and is married. She and her husband live in their own house with the basic essentials. They have three children. Telli has been the owner of a small general store for about a year. She sells foodstuffs for everyday use such as rice, flour, macaroni, soft drinks and sweets. Her monthly profit is 150-200 AZN. She also keeps a cow for her own use but would like to expand her business. 

The motivation for requesting a loan is to be able to purchase more merchandise to stock the business and to buy cattle. More products will attract more clients and generate a good monthly income to help her family. She dreams of, one day, opening her own store.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Antiqa

texts.en:
Antiqa J. has been selling foodstuffs and drinks in her grocery store for the past three years. She is a widow and raises four children alone. Hard living conditions pushed her to start her own business. As a true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences.

Antiqa is industrious and enterprising and is focused on expanding her business. She is currently seeking a loan of 500 AZN. She plans to use the loan to increase her assortment of fresh merchandise and to expand her business.

With the increased sales and profits, Antiqa hopes to expand her grocery store and to improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Zoraida

texts.es:
La  Sra.  Zoraida está  casada con el señor Miguel y tienen 4 hijos de los cuales 2 ya están casados  y 2 aun están en la escuela primaria. Viven en el barrio Fátima.  
Zoraida  tiene una despensa bien surtida y de buena ubicación en el barrio ya que la parada de ómnibus de la zona está ubicada frente a su casa. 
Ella se inició hace varios años con muy poca mercadería que poco a poco fue aumentando con el pasar de los años. 
 Hoy día ella tiene una despensa bien surtida y buenos precios, con una clientela formada. 
Además su marido es una persona muy trabajadora y con su trabajo ayuda con los gastos del hogar, 
El es responsable con sus compromisos.
Gracias al crédito que le hemos otorgado pudo aumentar su negocio con la compra de más mercaderías como harina, fideos, azúcar, arroz, panificados, enlatados y otros.
texts.en:
Señora Zoraida is married to Señor Miguel. They have four children, of whom two are already married and two still attend primary school. They live in the neighborhood of Fátima. Zoraida has a well stocked grocery store. It is in an excellent location in her neighborhood, since the local bus stop is right in front of her house. She started several years ago with just a few goods. As the years went by, her inventory increased progressively. Today her grocery store is well stocked and has attractive prices, which ensures an established customer base. In addition, her husband is a hard-working man and his work helps paying for household expenses. He respects his commitments. Thanks to the loan that we granted Zoraida, she could expand her business by purchasing more goods such as flour, noodles, sugar, rice, bread, canned food and other products.

Translated from Spanish by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, noodles, various soaps, and similar products

loans.name: Twegatte Women's Group-Kampala

texts.en:
Mukibi Annet, 57, belongs to the Twegatte Women’s group-Kampala.
Don’t compromise your principals and beliefs is the precept she has been using to push her retail shop. Her sand and firewood sales set her business horizons way beyond the boundaries of being mediocre and way ahead of her competitors. Having been a teacher, Annet says the proactiveness she used while teaching is still proving to be relevant. Annet is happily married and is a local councilor in her home area. In a week she makes profits that total 300,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more retail stock such as sugar, salt and beans. She also wants to buy more sand and firewood for resale.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, salt, beans and firewood for resale

loans.name: Taleh

texts.en:
Taleh A. is 31 years old. He is married and has one child. He is a small-business entrepreneur who sells different kinds of detergents like soap, shampoo, toothpaste, shaving cream and washing powder as well as foodstuffs in his store. His monthly income is 250-400 AZN. Taleh is not alone in this business. His wife actively helps him with sales. 

Today, Taleh is requesting a loan of 1000 AZN to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. Taleh’s main goal is to increase his profit enough to open one more store in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more food products

loans.name: Alikram

texts.en:
Alikram A. is 32 years old, married, and has two children. He owns a shop in which he sells spare moped engine parts, a business he has been running for the last 2 years. The average monthly income he earns, between $375 to $500, allows him to support his family, including his parents. 

To meet his customers’ constantly growing demand, Alikram would like to increase his shop’s capacity.  He applied for an 800 AZN loan. The profits from these sales will allow him to continue to improve his family's living conditions. The loan will greatly improve Alikram’s income and his family's standard of living.

loans.use: purchase more spare parts to increase profit

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr:
MARIE S. est une femme de 24 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WASSADOU depuis le 07 août 2009. 

MARIE S. est une commerçante. Elle vend diverses denrées alimentaires dans une boutique. Tels du lait en poudre dans des sachets, des boîtes de sardines, des biscuits etc. 

Elle s'est investie dans cette activité depuis environs 3 ans. Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer son approvisionnement en marchandises afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices.

Les bénéfices réalisés à partir de son activité lui permettront de mieux gérer sa famille, participer à la prise en charge de la scolarité, la nourriture, et la santé de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Marie S. is a 24-year old woman. She is married and mother to three children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in Wassadou since 7th August 2009. Marie is a businesswoman, who sells various food products in a shop. These include powdered milk in sachets, cans of sardines, biscuits etc. She has been active in this business for around three years. Her new loan will allow her to stock up with goods in order to make more money. The profits she makes from her business will allow her to manage her family better, contribute to her children's schooling, food and health expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get fresh supplies for her shop

loans.name: Alfa Y Omega 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Mayra is the coordinator of her group, Alfa y Omega 1 & 2 (Alfa and Omega). She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their 3 children. She says that her most difficult challenge was to start doing business.

Mayra is excited to be taking out her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for 8 years. She started with a savings of $70, selling vegetables and fruit from a small stall. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying some bags of rice, beans, flour and sugar. 

Her business is a Colmado, a place where you can find all the ingredients to make your daily meals. Normally those colmados are in the same neighborhood, a short walking distance from any home. She will use the profits to invest in her business, because she wants to have a large food market in the future.
 
This Esperanza associate began with us because she wants to invest in her business, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in San Pedro de Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and sugar cane industries. The main economic activity is the free trading zone, a cement factory, and others. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic suffers from unreliable electricity and running water (none of which is potable).

loans.use: to buy bags of  rice, beans, flour and sugar

loans.name: Kiira Women's Group-Jinja

texts.en:
A. Stella belongs to Kiira Women’s Group-Jinja. 

38-year-old A. Stella has brought hard work to bear the last seven years operating her retail shop which was gotten off its feet with the modest savings she had accumulated from her hawker business. The support of her husband was also instrumental in getting her business off its feet. Since then she has been steadfastly dedicated to the goals and set objectives that were laid down at the beginning of this business. 

She supplements her profits with a poultry business.  In a week this widowed mother of four made a profit of about $36. With this loan she is looking at buying more bags of sugar for resale.

loans.use: The buy more bags of sugar for resale

loans.name: Kyaterekera Development Group-Mpigi

texts.en:
She belongs to Kyaterekera Group-Mpigi.

35-year-old N. Sumayiya has a graceful persona that has endeared her to her retail shop customers for the last five years in Mpigi. Her general merchandise shop has been a melting pot of sorts with a variety customers patronizing her shop for goods. Ugandans are well known for their hospitality and here is a clear example of one. 

Sumayiya has taken it further in applying this to her business. In many ways she has been a benefactor of this. This high-spirited woman, who began with inspiration from a friend, says she makes about $44 a week. With the support of this loan she wants to buy more bags of sugar, maize flour, rice, beans, bars of soap, soft drinks, cups, candles, etc. for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of sugar, maize flour, rice, beans, etc. to resell

loans.name: Francia Elena

texts.es: Francia Elena tiene 31 años, su actividad es una pulpería que está ubicada en su casa de habitación, por lo que ha sido muy reconfortante pues ella tiene que hacerse cargo de su hijo que solamente tiene 3 años. este negocio inicio como una idea para sufragar los gastos diarios del hogar, por lo que con su esposo han logrado surtir, ella siempre esta brindado muy buena atención a sus clientes, se levanta muy temprano desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche. Ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de golosinas, jugos, refrescos, detergentes y granos básicos.
texts.en:
Francia Elena is 31 years old and runs a general store out of her house. This has been very comforting for her as she is able to care for her son who is only 3 years old. She started this business with the idea that it would help defray some of the daily household expenses. Along with her husband they have managed to stock the store. She always gives her customers very good attention. She gets up very early in morning and works from 7 am until 9 pm. She is requesting this loan to buy candy, juice, soft drinks, detergents and basic grains.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to stock her store

loans.name: Tabaksneh Group

texts.en:
In the photo are the members of the “Tabaksneh” group. They are women with small-scale businesses based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva.
