Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Babonere Kuiffe Women's Development Group-Jinja

texts.en:
B. Iren, aged 34, dreams of giving her family improved standards of living in the future. She belongs to the Babonere Kuiffe Group of Mpungwe-Jinja. Her tailoring and second-hand clothes' business, which she has been operating for the past seven years in Mpungwe-Jinja, has become a byword for good service and organisation. 

Iren is the married mother of four school-going children. She plans to buy more textile material  for making clothes and to buy clothes to resell once she accesses this Kiva loan. She started off by hiring sewing machines. 

Prior to beginning this business, she was mostly selling tomatoes and sweet bananas. Her business notwithstanding its many challenges generates close to 100,000 UGX a week. She lays this down to virtues like hard work, good customer care and friendliness. She says this loan will help her to expand her business. In her opinion, she will be in a position to buy more clothes and in reselling she will be establishing an advantage for her growing business, i.e. more profits.

loans.use: To buy material for making clothes and to buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Omungyenyi Kwetungura, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
T. Swibu belongs to the Omungyenyi Kwetungura, Ntungamo Group. Hard-working Swibu has operated a garment sales business for the past seven years from Rubaare trading centre. By selling clothes in monthly and weekly markets in the area, he earns 500,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. 

What has inspired him most in the business is having noticed the prevailing market in the area from local people. It is for this reason that he wants to get this loan to improve his financial prospects in terms of restocking his business with attractive materials and more bales of clothes. He earns additional income from farming and the ownership of a retail shop.

With these modest earnings, he has been able to make the best of the bad bargains that occasionally hit his garment sales business. Swibu happily reveals how he is able to educate his four-year-old child who is attending kindergarten. He is looking at business expansion in the future.

loans.use: To purchase materials and bales of clothes

loans.name: Maria Eugenia

texts.es:
María Eugenia es una mujer trabajadora, económicamente muy humilde, tiene la edad de 33 años, procreo cinco hijos, casada, siendo su esposo comerciante en acarreo que hace atreves de una jabalina con su caballo.
Su pequeño negocio es la venta de elote yoltamales, wirila logrando a si ganar dinero para cubrir los gastos ya que todo está  a costos altos.
Como madre es poder dar un techo digno  a sus hijos pero aun no lo logran, siendo su casa de zinc y tablas viejas, lo que urge hacer mejoras. 
Lo que optan al financiamiento para comenzar hacer las paredes de concreto ya que le es de mucha necesidad la construcción y que por falta de efectivo no lo han logrado.
Afodenic está siendo una puerta al cambio y mejora de su casa. Lo que está contenta por comenzar. Y que espera trabajar mucho en sus ventas diarias para lograr tener junto  a su esposo ahorros para ir pagando.
texts.en:
María Eugenia is a hard working woman of scarce economic resources. She is 33 years old, married and has five children. Her husband works as a hauler using his horse-drawn tractor. Her business is selling “yoltamales” (Nicaraguan sweet, corn tamales) and “wirila” (cheese and cinnamon-stuffed sweet corn tortilla) to earn income to cover expenses since everything is so expensive now. As a mother, she wants to provide a decent home for her children, something she hasn’t managed to do yet. Since her house is made of zinc metal sheeting and old boards; improvements are urgently needed. What they intend to do with the loan is build concrete walls since this construction is sorely needed but lack of funds has not allowed it so far. Afodenic is a path toward change and home improvement. She is happy to start and hopes to work hard at daily sales so that she and her husband together can have savings available to gradually repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy building materials and supplies like: gravel, sand, cement and iron rods to start building concrete walls and have a better home for her children.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Hard-working, dependable and die-hard agriculturalist, K. Wilson, aged 56 years, has been maintaining a banana plantation and coffee plantation for more than 20 years in his home area of Nombe, Ntungamo. This earns him 320,000 Ugandan shillings per month from banana sales, although not enough to sustain his family of seven children as some are still students attending different institutions of learning.

Wilson has persevered to keep the enterprise growing. His aim for taking up this loan is to enable him buy mulch and manure for his plantations as he seeks to expand by transporting his products to bigger markets. This will help him to increase productivity and also earn more revenue and be able to live a more sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase mulch and manure for his plantations

loans.name: Kamuri Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
A determined, hard-working T. Velogin, aged 43, of Kamuri Women's Group, Ntungamo, is a widowed mother of six. She has been operating a retail shop from Iterero trading centre, Ntungamo selling general merchandise especially home products like plastics, groceries, sugar, salt, maize flour, etc. She started this business 13 years ago with capital from her spouse and at the end of every month she is able to pocket profits to the tune of 170,000 Ugandan shillings. 

Her main drawback has been having limited stock in her business that cannot match her customers' rate of purchase. She is therefore seeking a loan to help her stock more goods that will satisfy the customers’ high demand and also transform her business into a bigger enterprise. 

Being very committed to the business and providing good customer care, she hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation in her business as she hopes to build a house for her family and will enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life, catering for her children’s education expenses.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for resale

loans.name: Namirembe Bakyara Tweheyo Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
As they say that determination leads to destiny, A. Emmanuel is gaining momentum in his charcoal-selling business which operates from the Kampala city markets. Many people tend to undermine casual work in Uganda but the 40-year-old married father of five children has been able to earn a living through this business for over 10 years. Charcoal is commonly used in Uganda as a form of energy in many homes to cook food and to warm houses when it's cold, as prices for paraffin, gas and electricity are always high. 

Through selling charcoal, Emmanuel is able to earn 323,000 Ugandan shillings monthly although having drawbacks such as not being able to transport his products to bigger markets. With this loan, he hopes to expand and supply his charcoal to larger charcoal markets. This will help to improve his sales revenue to cater for his family’s needs.

Emmanuel belongs to the Namirembe Bakyara Tweheyo Group, Ntungamo.

loans.use: To pay transportation costs providing access to bigger markets

loans.name: Rwabashenyi Fal, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
A determined and hard-working K. Peace, married with five children, is enthusiastic in terms of her agriculture businesses in Rwabashenyi, Ntungamo. She belongs to Rwabashenyi FAL, Ntungamo Group. Peace owns a banana plantation and other agricultural farms growing beans, millet and onions, all generating income for her family. This has seen her earn 300,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

Her main drawback has been the lack of funds to purchase mulch for her plantations. This has reduced the yields and she also now needs to buy more seedlings like onions for the coming season. This loan will therefore help her improve her banana produce yields thus enabling her to meet the customers’ high demand. It will also increase her sales revenue, hence making her more able to meet the family's requirements in terms of tuition fees for her children and to live a more self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase mulch and seedlings

loans.name: Matare Progressive Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
In the Kanungu trading centre of Kihihi, a hard-working and determined B. William has been running a business where he has sold food products for over a year. He belongs to the Matare Progressive Group, Kihihi. His hard work and friendly character have brought him this far alongside his other business of carpentry. Together, he earns 400,000 Ugandan shillings monthly from his businesses. 

This loan will help William to do research and purchase better quality products for selling such as rice, beans and coffee and to further restock his business in order to match the customers' demand. With an improved business, he will be able to earn more revenue and to support his family as he struggles to educate his nine children to create a better future for them.

loans.use: To buy more stock e.g. rice, beans and coffee

loans.name: Rushooka Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
As they say, hard work pays! K. Claudia, a very hardworking and determined woman, has reaped the fruits of her hard work having started up her restaurant enterprise over 20 years ago. She offers catering services in Rushooka Trading Centre, Ntungamo, preparing breakfast meals and local dishes for lunch and supper on her customers' menu.

Due to her good management and esteemed customer care, the business has maintained customers for a long time. The business has a strong clientele as they maintain good levels of hygiene. Most of her customers are town dwellers. With this loan, Claudia wants to put good furniture in place and also shop for restaurant supplies like foodstuff and drinks as she looks to improving the quality of services offered. This will enable her to get more customers, earn more profit and be able to provide her family and children’s requirements like education. She is very optimistic she will achieve a self-sustaining lifestyle with more income coming her way. 

K. Claudia belongs to Rushooka Women's Group, Ntungamo.

loans.use: To restock foodstuffs and furnish her restaurant

loans.name: Rwenyerere Bakyara Tukwatanise Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
As they say, hard work pays! K. Grace, a very hardworking and determined woman, has reaped the fruits of her hard work having started up her clothes selling enterprise over 10 years ago. She offers secondhand clothes in Rushooka Trading Centre, Ntungamo, where she responds to the seasonal markets being close to her customers.

Due to her good management and esteemed customer care, she has maintained customers for a long time creating a good market.  With this loan, Grace wants to buy more clothes for resale. Since she also has a farming business, she also wants to buy more seedlings and manure for her plantations. This will enable her to make more profit and be able to provide for her family and children’s requirements like education. She is very optimistic she will achieve a self-sustaining lifestyle with more income coming her way. 

K. Grace belongs to Rwenyerere Bakyara Tukwatanise Group, Kihihi.

loans.use: Restocking more bales of clothes

loans.name: Rwashamaire Bakyara Kwebeisaho Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
R. Frida is a hardworking, cheerful, 65-year-old married mother with six buoyant, enthusiastic and mature children, some of whom are still enrolled in higher institutions of learning. She operates a grocery shop in Rwashamaire Trading Centre, Ntungamo, selling agricultural produce like cassava, jack fruits, sweet potatoes, sweet bananas and more. This has lasted for two years and, with earnings from this business, she has managed to educate her children. She is also a farmer selling bananas from her plantation in Rwashamaire.

Frida's likable nature has attracted many customers to her business daily. She earns 240,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. She is looking forward to giving her business a greater boost after getting this loan. With this loan, she wants to buy agro produce to expand her business. 

Frida belongs to Rwashamaire Bakyara Kwebeisaho Group, Ntungamo.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs like sweet bananas, cassava and jack fruits

loans.name: Busabaga Development Group-Lugazi

texts.en: Caroline B. belongs to Busabaga Development Group-Lugazi. She has run a tailoring business in Busabaga-Lugazi for four years now. Before that she sold snacks and she used the profits from that business to start her tailoring business. Caroline is married with four children. She earns about 100,000 shillings (UGX) per week. She will use this loan to buy more cloth material for her tailoring business.  Her dream is to build a house for her family and provide an education for her children.

loans.use: To buy cloth for tailoring.

loans.name: Akutwala Ekiro Kyebando Kisalosalo Group

texts.en: Caroline O. belongs to Akutwala Ekiro Kyebando Kisalosalo group loan. She sells charcoal to make ends meet for herself and her husband and five children. She has been in this business for the last 5 years in Kyebando-Kampala. It is through friends that she got the idea to start this business. Before that she was more inclined to sell clothes. She describes herself as an optimist bent on achieving success in whatever she does. She can earn as much as 500,000 shillings (UGX) each month selling charcoal. She also sells cereals like maize for additional income. With this loan, she will be able to buy more bags of charcoal for reselling.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for selling.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es: El Señor Juan Carlos G. E. tiene la edad de 55 años de edad, es casado tienen 6 hijos mayores de edad, 5 de ellos son independientes del Sr. G. el menor de sus hijos de 15 años de edad, es el único que depende de su padre este, se encuentra estudiando la secundaria y pronto entrara a la universidad, el señor Juan Carlos labora como conductor de camión, luego aprendió los oficios de soldadura y mecánica, fue de esta manera que inicio con su taller, por el mismo solicita un préstamo para la compra de zinc, perlines, arena y cemento para ampliar el local y brindar una mejor atención para su clientela, y de esta forma el aumento en las ventas y la mejora continua de sus condiciones económicas para el apoyo a los estudios universitarios a su hijo menor.
texts.en:
Sr. Juan Carlos G. E. is 55 years old, married, and has six children, five of whom are independent. His youngest child is 15 years old and the only one who is still a dependent. Upon finishing high school, his son will enter immediately into the university.

Sr. Juan Carlos worked as a truck driver, but he later received training in the welding and mechanical trades. This allowed him to open his own workshop. Juan Carlos is requesting a loan to buy zinc, crossbeams, sand, and cement to expand his studio and provide better service to his customers. This will allow him to increase his sales and continue improving his economic situation so that he can support his youngest son with his university studies.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to remodel his business

loans.name: Margarito Antonio

texts.es: El señor Margarito Antonio C., tiene la edad de 50 años vive en el barrio la Borgoña, es casado y tiene 3 hijos adolecentes que se dedican a los estudios secundarios, ellos tiene una experiencia de más de 30 años  en la actividad de la agricultura, las plagas y las enfermedades en las tierras han dificultado una buena cosecha, con el apoyo de su padre conoció acerca de las labores de su negocio, ahora solicita un préstamo para la compra de insumos y fertilizantes que brinden un mejor mantenimiento a sus cultivos para el aumento de sus ventas y la mejora de su economía a favor de que su hijo mayor entrara próximamente a la universidad y necesitan de mejores condiciones económicas para suplir los gastos, todo para un mejor porvenir para su hijo. Este no es el primer prestamo con Afodenic el Señor tiene un excelente record crediticio, y hemos notado su mejoria economica a raiz del apoyo que se le ha brindado.
texts.en:
Sr. Margarito Antonio C. is 50 years old and lives in the neighborhood of Borgoña. He is married and has three teenage children who are high school students. Margarito has more than 30 years of experience farming. Pests and diseases can harm his land and make it difficult for him to achieve a good harvest. With the help of his father, Margarito learned how to work in this business.

He is now requesting a loan to purchase supplies and fertilizers so that he can provide the best care for his crops, which will allow him to increase his sales and improve his finances. This will favor his oldest son who will be starting soon at the university. Margarito needs to improve his financial condition so that he can pay for his son’s expenses and provide him a better future. This is not the first loan he has received from AFODENIC and he has an excellent credit record. It should be noted that Margarito’s economic situation has improved after financial support was provided.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies & fertilizers

loans.name: Twekembe Kabungo Namutamba Group-Mityana

texts.en: Rosco N., age 72, belongs to Kabungo Twekembe group loan.  He is a poised, well-rounded, diligent, and clear-sighted man which explains his success the past 12 years working as a butcher. Rosco worked previously in a retail enterprise, and that is how he saved money to begin his current butcher shop business in Butumbirizi of Mityana. He can earn 100,000 shillings (UGX) in one week, and often earns more profits from selling milk.  With this loan he will purchase cattle for butchering. His dream is to start a cattle farm.

loans.use: To buy cattle for his butchery.

loans.name: Abel De Jesús

texts.es: El Señor Abel de Jesús R. M., tiene la edad de 29 años vive en el Barrio la Francia se dedica a la agricultura, tienen un bebe recién nacido de 6 meses de edad, desde hace 10 años se ganan el sustento diario gracias a la actividad de la agricultura, fue con el apoyo de su padre que conoció de este oficio, pero con el paso del tiempo, la afectación de las plagas y enfermedades, le han disminuido la producción afectando su economía, razón que no le permite el ahorro para la remodelación de su vivienda, es por esto que solicita un préstamo para la inversión a su negocio en la compra de fertilizantes, fungicidas, insumos vegetativos, que le brinden un mejor mantenimiento a sus terrenos y a futuro permita mejores condiciones de habitad para su pequeña familia.
texts.en:
Abel de Jesús R. M. is 29 years old, and he lives in the La Francia neighborhood. He is a farmer. He has a newborn baby who is six months old. For ten years he has been earning his daily living through farming. It was with his father’s support the he learned this line of work. However, with the passage of time pests and diseases have diminished production, which affects his finances. That is why he has not been able to save to remodel his house. That is why he is requesting a loan to invest in his business. He will buy fertilizers, fungicides, and vegetative supplies. These will provide his fields with improved maintenance, and in the future it will allow for improved living conditions for his small family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improved maintenance on his crops

loans.name: Marlon Antonio

texts.es: El señor Marlon Antonio A. J., es un joven de 29 años casado con dos niños de 9 y 5 añitos, ellos habitan en el Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla, su esposa se dedica a las actividades domesticas, el señor es asalariado y es la fuente de los ingresos de la familia, ellos habitan en una humilde morada, que con las fuertes lluvias de invierno le ha deteriorado aun mas su vivienda, fue con el apoyo de su esposa y el esfuerzo propio que lograron la construcción de su casita, pero ahora solicitan un préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción para la remodelación del baño y la sala, este apoyo les brindara un espacio mas salubre y comodidades, sobre todo para el señor A. de beneficiar a su familia con un ambiente digna  a desarrollarse.
texts.en:
Mr. Marlon Antonio A. J. is a Young 29-year-old man. He’s married and has two children who are 9 and 5 years of age. They live in Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla. His wife is a housewife and he is a salaried employee and the main source of family income. They live in a humble home which has deteriorated even more due to winter rains. He had managed to build his house with his own efforts and help from his wife but now needs a loan to buy building materials and supplies to remodel the bathroom and living room. This help will provide more sanitary and comfortable spaces, especially because Mr. A. so wants to provide a proper home for his family to develop in.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For bathroom and living room remodel.

loans.name: Kyaliwajala  Womens Group A -Kampala

texts.en: Jane N., age 35, belongs to the Kyaliwajjala Group in Kampala. This mother of five has operated a retail shop for a year and a half, selling merchandise such as sugar, salt, beans, rice, flour, and other cooking supplies. She also earns additional income raising pigs and selling charcoal.  Jane credits her husband who helped her get started with his financial support. Before opening her shop, she sold bricks and raised crops. Now, she can earn about 100,000 shillings (UGX) per week.  With this loan she will buy merchandise for her shop.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Kyaliwajala Group-Kampala

texts.en: Mary N., age 49, belongs to Kyaliwajala Group-Kampala. Mary is a high-spirited entrepreneurial woman with a decade-long track record running her restaurant in Kyaliwajala-Kampala. Mary credits close friends who she says helped her summon the courage, diligence, and resolve to be successful. Agriculture was her first business. Mary also operates a poultry business. In a week this happily-married mother of five can earn up to 120,000 shillings (UGX). She feels this loan will go a long way in empowering her, and she will use it to pay school fees for her children and to revamp her restaurant business.

loans.use: To pay school fees and revamp her restaurant.

loans.name: Mukama Mwesigwa Group B-1- Kampala

texts.en: She is highly spirited when it comes to running her business and she belongs to Mukama Mwesigwa B Group in Kampala. This virtue has been 27-year-old N. Winnie’s trump card in establishing a niche for her beauty salon and clothes business in Nateete Park, Kampala. This divorced mother of two started off with savings from a bakery business that she was running with her husband. She earns 60,000 shillings a week. With this loan, she is looking at buying more cosmetics for her beauty salon and also new clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics for her beauty salon and new clothes to resell

loans.name: Mukama Mwesigwa Group B-2-Kampala

texts.en: 26-year-old K. Flore belongs to Mukama Mwesigwa B Group from Kampala. For the last 5 years, she has subsisted on profits from her general merchandise retail shop in Nateete. She began this business with savings from her farming business. She attributes some of her success to her adherence to the golden rules she laid down at the start of her business. Hard work, tenacity and determination have brought favorable changes to her business operations. In a week, this good-humouredly smiling mother of two makes 250,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more retail goods for her shop. She is looking at buying items like bags of sugar, rice, beans and maize flour.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of sugar, rice, beans and maize flour

loans.name: Herminda Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Herminda del Carmen, tiene la edad de 42 años, vive acompañada de su pareja de vida en el barrio Laureles Norte, tiene con su pareja 3 hijos mayores de edad de  los cuales los dos mayores trabajan y apoyan a sus padres en los gastos del hogar, la menor estudia la secundaria y depende económicamente  de sus padres, ellos tiene una pulpería desde hace mas de 7 años, por los problemas económicos que atraviesa el país sus ventas son variables, antes trabajaba en un zona franca y con sus ahorro y su liquidación fue que inicio su negocio de venta de abarrotes, productos para el hogar, y personal.

Su hija pronto entrara a la universidad y espera tener los recursos Económicos para apoyarla a mejorar su calidad de vida, ahora solicita un préstamo para la compra de  un mayor inventario de mercadería  para su negocio que garantice un incremento en sus ventas y condiciones propias para llevar a cabo los estudios de su hija menor.
Este es el tercer ciclo de la señroa con el apoyo que se le ha brindado, ha mostrado una gran mejoria economica, pues es una mejer trabajadora responsable y con mucha iniciativa en el trabajo.
texts.en:
Herminda del Carmen, 42, lives with her life partner in the Laureles North neighborhood. With her partner she has 3 grown children, two of whom work and help their parents with the household expenses. The youngest is in high school and is economically dependent. Herminda and her partner have had a general store for more than 7 years. Due to the economic problems that are affecting the country, her sales are variable. Previously, she was working in the free trade zone, and with her savings and severance pay she started her business selling groceries, products for the home and personal products. Her daughter will soon enter the university, and she hopes to have the financial resources to support her effort to improve her quality of life. Now she requests a loan to buy a greater quantity of merchandise for her business to ensure an increase in her sales so that she can support her daughter's education. This is Herminda's 3rd loan cycle, and with the support that has been provided to her she has shown great economic improvement. She is a very hardworking and responsible woman who shows a lot of initiative in her work.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase the inventory in her store

loans.name: Shamshibek

texts.en:
Shamshibek T. is a 60-year-old pensioner, who supports his family by means of cattle breeding. He worked as an engineer at an agro-technical company for 40 years and was known as a very steady and responsible person. Unfortunately, pensions in rural areas are low and people need to find an additional means of subsistence to live on. For this reason, Shamshibek’s family decided to engage in cattle breeding. 

As Shamshibek was born into a farmer’s family and had wide experience in animal breeding, he started this activity with great enthusiasm. He used his initial capital of only 5,000 soms (KGS) to buy cattle and managed to increase the number. Also, Shamshibek began to cultivate sunflowers and perennial herbs which serve as concentration of forage for his cattle. With the revenue, Shamshibek gave a good education to his children which allowed them to successfully manage their lives. 

Now Shamshibek plans to use this loan of 80,000 KGS to buy more cattle for fattening and reselling. He wants to use the revenue from this loan to help his son buy his own house. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei is married. He has been in business for five years. He started as a taxi driver. Later, he began to help people with various construction projects. About a year ago he was able to open his own store, selling plumbing and construction materials. Sergei is very entrepreneurial. He wants to develop this business further and serve many satisfied clients.

Sergei is requesting a loan of 10,000 hryvnias to purchase more inventory for his store. He would like to invest the money he makes back into this business. Sergei's wife and two sons help him with this business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Abahuza Group

texts.fr:
Célestin N., née à Rubavu l’Ouest du pays en 1975, il est marié, il a cinq enfants, son ainé a 15 ans et son cadet a 7 ans et il n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il vit avec sa famille à Kigali tous ses enfants vont à l’école.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire des transporteurs Taxi Moto appelé ABAHUZA, qui est un groupe dont les membres font le transport des personnes avec moto et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Célestin et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie quelques uns ont pu construire leurs maisons, Célestin, lui aussi est motard (un nom des transporteurs des personnes en taxi-moto au Rwanda), il veut commencer le projet de construction d’une habitation. En fait, le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les pièces de rechanges pour leurs motos et d’autres pour business de leurs femmes. Les membres de ce groupe ont l’habitude d’épargner pour la préparation de leur bon futur.
N.B : Le groupe contient 12 membres mais 10 sont disponibles sur la photo car les deux qui manques sont malade.
texts.en:
Célestin N. was born in Rubavu (Western Rwanda) in 1975. He is married and the father of five children. The oldest is 15 and the youngest 7. The family lives in Kigali. Célestin did not attend school, but all his children do so. Célestin is a member of the Cooperative Abahuza. It is an association of motorbike taxi drivers who work together and guarantee each other's loans. Célestin and his group work hard to provide for their families and improve their living conditions. A few of them were able to build their house. Célestin, too, is a motard (the name of motorbike taxi drivers in Rwanda). He wants to start the construction of his house. The group did take out a loan from Amasezerano Community Banking to buy spare parts for their motorbikes and also to bolster the businesses of their wives. The group members are used to save regularly some money to secure their future. NB: The group is made up of twelve members. Only ten are pictured, because two of them were sick.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cement, sand, bricks and planks to build their houses

loans.name: Tetyana

texts.en:
Tetyana is married with two children. She lives in Novomoskovsk and owns a small business. Tetyana raises and sells chickens. She has been in this business for 10 years. Some of chickens she raises for sale herself. Others she buys directly from chicken farms and then sells retail. Tetyana is very enthusiastic about her business. She enjoys it and would like to develop it further.

Tetyana is requesting a loan of 13,000 hryvnias. She needs to purchase food to feed her chickens during the fall season. She hopes to have good sales at the end of the season and receive additional profit to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and feed

loans.name: Rey

texts.en:
Rey C. is from the city of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Rey is the one next to the motorcycle. He is 23 years old and single. To make a living, Rey owns and operates a business venture, operating transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motor transport services. Rey has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rey joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rey is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair his existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the first taken out by Rey from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle for better service

loans.name: María Rosario

texts.es:
La Señora María Rosario P. es socia del banco comunal San Pablo, vive en la comunidad de Los Laureles en donde su gente se dedica a la cría de anímeles y a la agricultura, muchos salen a la ciudad a realizar varios trabajos, también mucha de su población ha migrado a otros países en busca de un mejor futuro para sus familias.

Doña María tiene 57 años, es casada y tiene 6 hijos quienes son mayores de edad, cuatro de ellos son casados y viven de manera independiente, sus dos hijos solteros trabajan pero no le ayudan ya que el sueldo que ganan es solo para sus gastos, su esposo se dedica a la construcción ya que es maestro albañil, gracias al trabajo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.

La Señora. María se dedica a la venta de frutas y legumbres actividad que la realiza ambulantemente por los mercados de la ciudad de Cuenca, trabaja en esta labor desde que tenía 12 años ya que su madre le  enseño esta actividad. También se dedica a la cría de animales como son pollos y cuyes a los cuales los vende cuando tiene alguna necesidad en su propia comunidad.

Es nuestra socia hace 2 años y ha sido incentivada por una amiga que pertenece al banco comunal a formar parte de este grupo de mujeres luchadoras. Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más frutas para incrementar su negocio.
 
Su meta es seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
María Rosario P. is a member of the San Pablo Communal Bank. She lives in the Los Laureles community. The people in this community raise animals and farm. Many people leave the city to perform various jobs. Also, much of the population has migrated to other countries looking for a better future for their families. María, age 57, is married and has six grown children. Four of her children are married and live independently. Two of her children are single and work. However, they do not help her because the salary they earn is only for their expenses. Her husband works in construction. He is a master bricklayer. Thanks to their communal work they managed to build their own house. María sells fruits and vegetables in an itinerant manner at the markets in the city of Cuenca. She has been doing this work since she was 12 years old. Her mother taught her this work. Also, she raises animals like chickens and guinea pigs. When she needs to, she sells them in her own community. She has been a member for two years. A friend who belongs to the communal bank encouraged to form part of this group of tenacious women. She will use the new loan to buy more fruit to increase her business. Her goal is to keep growing in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bananas, oranges, coconuts, stawberries, and papayas, etc.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna H. is from the village of Poblacion 1, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Lorna is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a transportation service. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motor transport services. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Lorna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Lorna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Rita L.

texts.en:
Rita L.O. is from the village of Segatic Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 72 years old. Rita is married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Rita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting bananas for sale. Rita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Rita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Rita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: María Jesús

texts.es:
La Señora María Jesús A. es socia del banco comunal San Pablo, vive en la comunidad de San Pablo que pertenece a la parroquia de Turi, esta comunidad se encuentra a 10 minutos de la ciudad de Cuenca, su gente mayor se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura, mucha de su gente busca en la ciudad  mejores oportunidades de trabajo.

La Señora María se encuentra hace tres años en la banca comunal y está muy contenta  de pertenecer a este 
grupo de mujeres luchadoras, los créditos anteriores le han beneficiado mucho en su negocio. Se dedica a la venta de frutas, es una comerciante ambulante que realiza esta actividad hace 10 años y gracias a este trabajo ha logrado salir  adelante junto a su familia.

Doña María tiene 64 años, es viuda  hace 13 años y tiene 6 hijos de 43, 38, 36, 27, 25, 23 años de edad, sus dos  primeros hijos son solteros y lo que trabajan es  para sus gastos, sus cuatro hijos casados viven de manera independiente. Vive en su casa propia que ya esta viejita por el paso de los años.
  
Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más frutas para incrementar su negocio ya que su meta es seguir manteniendo el mismo.
texts.en:
María Jesús A. is a member of the San Pablo Communal Bank. She lives in the San Pablo community, which is in the Turi parrish. This community is ten minutes from the city of Cuenca. Most of the people in the community raise animals and farm. Many people look for better work opportunities in the city. María has been in the communal bank for three years. She is very happy to belong to this group of tenacious women. The previous loans have benefited her business a great deal. She sells fruit as an itinerant salesperson. She has been doing this for ten years. Thanks to this work she has managed to get ahead together with her family. María is 64 years old, and she has been a widow for 13 years. She has six children; ages 43, 38, 36, 27, 25, and 23. Her first two children are single, and they work for their expenses. Her four married children live independently. She lives in her own house, which is old due to the passage of time. She will use the new loan to buy more fruit to increase her business. Her goal is to continue maintaining her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy oranges, coconuts, papayas, pineapples, and bananas, etc.

loans.name: Darlene

texts.en:
Darlene D. is from the city of Mabini Annex, Ozamiz city. She is 30 years old and is married with three infant children. Darlene owns and operates a business providing motor transport services. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 9,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Darlene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Darlene is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to repair her vehicle in order to provide better service. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Carmita Maricela

texts.es:
La Señora Carmita Maricela Z. es socia del banco comunal San Pablo, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca,  esta ciudad es conocida por la cultura que encierra cada rincón de su centro histórico, es cuna de grandes atletas y escritores, cuenta con una gran variedad de platos típicos y es la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador.

Este es el tercer año que nuestra socia realiza los créditos en la fundación junto al banco comunal. Se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos de Avon, Yanbal y  L´bel, esta actividad la realiza de lunes a viernes desde las 9 a.m. hasta las 8 p.m. y los sábados se dedica a la venta de frutas actividad que la realiza hace 7 años.

Doña Carmita tiene 28 años,  es casada y tiene 3 hijos de 9, 7 y 4 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos estudian en una escuela de la ciudad, su esposo trabaja en una fabrica, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.

Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más frutas para tener una gran variedad de la misma.

Su mayor sueño es  llegar a tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Carmita Maricela Z. is a member of the San Pablo Communal Bank. She lives in the city of Cuenca. This city is known for the culture that envelops each corner of its historical center. It is the cradle of great athletes and writers, and it has a great variety of typical dishes. It is the third most important city in Ecuador. This is the third year that she has had loans with the Fundación together with her communal bank. She sells clothes and Avon, Yanbal, and L´bel cosmetics. She does this Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. until 8 p.m. On Saturdays she sells fruit, which she has been doing for seven years. Carmita, age 28, is married and has three children. The children are nine, seven, and four years old. The first two go to school in the city. Her husband works in a factory. They do not have their own house; they rent where they live. The new loan is to buy fruit in order to have a greater variety. Her biggest dream is to come to have her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy papayas, pineapples, bananas, cantaloupes, and watermelons, etc.

loans.name: Blanca Leonor Del Carmen

texts.es:
La Señora Blanca Leonor E. es socia del banco comunal Tres Marías, vive en las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca en la comunidad que lleva el mismo nombre, en esta comunidad su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y también a la agricultura, mucha de su población buscan en la ciudad una mejor oportunidad de trabajo para mejorar sus situaciones económicas.
 
Doña Blanca tiene 51 años, es viuda hace 6 años y tiene 4 hijos de 30, 27, 22, 19 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos son casados y viven  independientemente y sus  dos últimos hijos estudian en la universidad, la casa en la que habitan no es de su propiedad por lo que viven arrendando.

La Señora Blanca se dedica a la venta de comida rápida en un kiosco, lleva 10 años con este negocio, trabaja los 7 días de la semana desde las 4 de la tarde hasta las 9 de la noche. 

Se encuentra trabando con los créditos en la banca comunal hace 5 años y ahora con el nuevo crédito que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le hace entrega lo va a invertir en arreglar el  kiosco de su negocio.
 
Su mayor sueño es tener su casa y ponerse un mini mercado.
texts.en:
Blanca Leonor E. is a member of community bank, Tres Marías. She lives on the outskirts of the city of Cuenca in a community of the same name. The local community raises animals and works the land. Many of the local people look for a better opportunity working in the city to improve their economic situation. Blanca is 51 years old, and has been a widow for six years. She has four children ages 30, 27, 22, and 19 years old. Her first two children are married and live independently; her remaining children are studying at the university. Blanca does not have her own house and instead rents. Blanca sells fast-food from a kiosk for a living and has been doing this for the past 10 years. She works 7 days a week, from 4pm till 9 o’clock at night. She is able to work using the loans that the community bank has provided her for the past 5 years, and with this new loan from the Fundación Espoir, Blanca can reinvest into her business by revamping her kiosk. Blanca’s dream is to own her own house and set up a mini-market.

Translated from Spanish by Justine Raymond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Revamp a food stand/kiosk.

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Khem R., 46, is widowed and lives with her only child in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known as the most populated city in the country. R. is a housewife while her daughter is employed in a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.

R. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase rice to stock and sell. By doing so, she is able to generate more income for her family. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

In the future, R. would like to use any additional profit to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy rice to stock and sell

loans.name: Gloria Fabiola

texts.es:
La Señora Gloria Fabiola G. es socia del banco comunal Tres Marías, vive en las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca por el sector del Control Sur, la mayor parte de su población buscan en la ciudad una mejor oportunidad de trabajo para mejorar sus situaciones económicas.
 
La Señora Gloria se dedica a la comercialización de zapatos, lleva 7 años en este negocio, trabaja recorriendo diferentes lugares de la ciudad ya que no cuenta con un puesto propio, su horario de trabajo es de 9:30 a.m. a 2 p.m. de domingo a domingo.
 
Doña Gloria tiene de 32 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos de 18, 13, 9 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos estudian en el colegio y su ultimo hijo estudia en la escuela de la ciudad, su esposo también es comerciante de zapatos, la casa en la que habitan no es de su propiedad por lo que vive arrendando.
 
Lleva 5 años trabajando en la banca comunal y los créditos otorgados le han beneficiado mucho en su negocio para la compra de mercadería, el nuevo crédito que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le hace entrega lo va a invertir para surtir más mercadería.
 
Su meta es llegar a tener un  almacén de calzado.
texts.en:
Ms. Gloria Fabiola G. is a member of the Tres Marías communal bank. She lives in the suburbs of the city of Cuenca, in the Control Sur sector. Most of the population of Control Sur looks to the city for better opportunities to work and improve their economic situations. Ms. Gloria sells shoes. She has been working in this business for 7 years. She works by walking through different places around the city, as she does not have her own stand. Her work schedule is from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m. from Sunday to Sunday. Ms. Gloria is 32 years old, married, and has 3 children aged 18, 13, and 9 years old. Her two older children are studying in high school, and her youngest son studies at a school in the city. Her husband is also a shoe salesman. The house where they live is not their own, as they are renting it. She has been working with the communal bank for 5 years and the loans she has been granted have really benefited her business by allowing her to purchase merchandise. She is going to invest this new loan from Fundación ESPOIR to stock more merchandise. Her goal is to have a shoe store.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy shoes

loans.name: Mun

texts.en:
Mun S., 24, is married, and lives with her husband and child in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, known as the most populated city in the country. S. is a housewife while her husband is a tailor, earning an income of USD 15 per day. S.'s husband appears in the photograph using scissors to design clothes.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to purchase supplements to run a food shop. By doing so, she will be able to generate more income for her family. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

In the future, S. would like to use her profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy supplements to run a food shop

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao B., 36, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, known as the most populated city in the country. B. is a housewife while her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 5 per day. B.'s husband appears in the photograph because B. was not available.

B. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a tuk-tuk (a motorcycle-based taxi) to enable her husband to expand his current business. By doing so, her husband will be able to generate more income for his family.  This is B.’s first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

In the future, B. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy a tuk tuk to expand her husband's transportation business

loans.name: Sara Esperanza

texts.es:
La Señorita Sara Esperanza L. es socia del banco comunal Tres Marías, vive en las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca en la comunidad que lleva el mismo nombre, en esta comunidad su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y también a la agricultura, mucha de su población buscan en la ciudad una mejor oportunidad de trabajo para mejorar sus situaciones económicas.
 
Doña Sara tiene 43 años y es soltera, vive en  casa de su mamá ya que ella le atiende y le cuida por su  avanzada edad.
 
La Señorita Sara se ha dedicado desde muy joven a la costura y ahora posee su propio taller el cual está ubicado en su domicilio, lleva 16 años en su negocio y fue su hermana la que le enseño esta actividad, también se dedica a la agricultura y a la cría de animales como borregos, chanchos y cuyes.
 
Trabaja hace 4 años con los créditos de la banca comunal y ha sido su sobrina y su hermana la que la incentivó a formar parte de este grupo de mujeres  luchadoras, el nuevo crédito que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le hace entrega lo va a invertir en la reparación de una máquina de su taller y en la compra de animales.
 
Su meta es crecer  en su taller.
texts.en:
Sara Esperanza L. is a member of the Tres Marías communal bank. She lives in the outskirts of Cuenca in a communiy also called Tres Marías. Residents of this community are farmers and raise animals. Much of the population seeks employment in the city in hopes of improving their economic situation. Sara is 43 years old and single. She lives in her mother’s house because she is the one charged with caring for her elderly mother. From a very young age Sara has been a seamstress and now has her own workshop in her home. She has had the business for 16 years; her sister taught her these skills. She also farms and raises animals like: lambs, pigs and guinea pigs. She has had loans with the communal bank for 4 years. Her sister and niece encouraged her to join this group of tenacious women. The new loan that FUNDACION ESPOIR grants will be used to repair one of the sewing machines in her workshop and to purchase animals. Her goal is to grow in her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair a sewing machine and to buy guinea pigs, lambs and pigs.

loans.name: Bech's Group

texts.en:
These are five men who are taking this loan together, all of whom live in the province of Siem Reap. The group's leader, Mr. Bech R., is 19 years old, married and has two small kids. He helps meet the financial crisis of his family buy working as a porter in the local fish market. His wife works with him at the same location. Bech R.’s house has suffered because of the heavy rainfall and it needs repairs. In view of that, Bech R. has taken out a loan in order to mend his old house. 

The other borrowers include: 

K., a fish porter, who is asking for a loan to repair his broken house.

S. will use this loan for his wife to invest in her grocery business.

V., a fish currying laborer, is applying for a loan to buy housing material for mending his old house. 

K. needs a loan to add with his savings in order to buy an old motorcycle for commuting to work.

loans.use: To mend his old house.

loans.name: Teresita Gay

texts.en:
Teresita Gay S. is from the village of Siare. She is 50 years old. Teresita Gay is widowed and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresita Gay owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Teresita Gay has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Teresita Gay joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita Gay has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita Gay is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Teresita Gay from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:

To make a living, She runs a general store,  selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately $200 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Virgilia L. Group.

Virgilia is widowed and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Virgilia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store, selling clothing and shoe products in the local community. Virgilia is just starting this business.

In 2010, Virgilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 1st loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Rosela B. is from the village of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga. She is 62 years old, married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, she produces corn to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately $58 a month for these activities.

She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosela is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used for corn production. This will be her 12th loan from PMPC.
