loans.name: Cynthia Servande Group

texts.en:
Cynthia Servande is from the town of Naga, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is 51 years old and the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Cynthia Servande Group.

Cynthia is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately $115 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cynthia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. 

Cynthia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of her extended family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
Gloria B. is from the village of Birayan, Rizal. She is 51 years old and the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Gloria is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, she sells fruit. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 26 years and earns approximately $79 a month for this activity.

In 2006, Gloria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Gloria is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used as additional working capital for the business. This will be her 8th loan from PMPC.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Alfreda

texts.en:
Alfreda S. is from the village of Salimpuno, Sapang Dalaga. She is 28 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she plants and sells assorted crops. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately $70 a month for these activities.

In 2006, Alfreda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. 

Alfreda is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used for corn production. This will be her 8th loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for corn production

loans.name: Chann's Group

texts.en:
This small group loan is made up of four members, all residents of the rural area of Siem Reap Province. The members have chosen Mrs. Chann S. as the group leader.

Chann S. is 48 years old and earns a living as a domestic tailor, sewing or mending clothes for her villagers. She has five teenage children: two work driving a boat for tourists and the other three attend school. Her husband is skilled in building houses, knowledge he uses to earn a living.

Chann S. is taking her first loan to buy tailoring accessories to perform her sewing service.

The other borrowers who are jointly taking this loan are:

Mrs. S. is applying for a loan to increase the capital of her fish-selling business.

Mrs. P., a grocery trader, is applying for a loan to increase her inventory.

Mrs. N., a fish-seller, is asking for a loan to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy tailoring accessories to perform her sewing service

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie L. is from the village of Tolon, Rizal. She is 39 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Rosalie owns and operates a business producing corn to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Rosalie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita G. is from the village of Tabon. She is 57 years old and is married with four adult children. Rosita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty-seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Rosita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bonifacio

texts.en: Bonifacio S. is from the village of Tamil. He is 38 years old and is a widower with two school-aged children. Bonifacio owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Bonifacio joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be his first from PMPC. Bonifacio plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

location.town: Tamil, Jose Dalman Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Tuon's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four low-income people who live together in Siem Reap province. Mrs. Tuon P., age 41, has been selected to be the leader of the group.

Tuon P. has been selling a few groceries since early in 2007. She is a widowed mother who is blessed with two children.

Recently, Tuon P.’s grocery stock has been exhausted; she wants to resupply her stock and is applying for a loan in order to buy a large amount of grocery inventory to continue selling.

The other borrowers who have jointly taken this loan are:

Mrs. S., a clothes vender, who is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to sell.

Mr. S., a taxi driver, who is asking for a loan to replace his old taxi that breaks down often.

Mrs. S., who will use her loan to redecorate her porridge shop in order to attract more customers.

loans.use: To buy a large amount of grocery inventory

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex M. is 41 years old and is from the town of Surallah. He is married with three young school-aged boys. Farming is the source of income for his family.

He wants to give his kids a better future. That is the reason why he is working hard on his farming business and is requesting a loan to improve his yield. The loan will be used to buy fertilizers and seedlings. His profit will be used to finance his children’s schooling and as savings for the future.

loans.use: purchase of fertilizers and seedlings

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Like most people in Surallah, 63-year-old Antonio S. is in the farming business. He is married and has two grown children. He wants to be of help to his children and their families. 

He applied for a loan to finance his farm's maintenance and will buy fertilizer, seedlings and other farming tools. He wants to increase the profitability of his business. His income will go toward his family’s daily needs, to help his children and as savings for the future.

loans.use: purchase of fertilizers, seedlings and other farming tools

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina P. is 31 years old and the mother of three young girls. Her family lives in Santo Niño, Surallah. 

She has been farming since having her family. This has been their source of livelihood. Like most mothers, she wants her children to have a life quite different from hers. She realized that she could do better with her farming if given financial assistance. 

She requested a loan to be used in buying seedlings and fertilizers. The extra income that she can get from this will be used for her family’s daily needs and for her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda P. is from the village of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga. She is 53 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she raises and sells pigs from her own farm. She has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities. 

In 2004, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. 

Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for hog raising. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for hog raising

loans.name: Cesar

texts.en:
Cesar M. has been a rice farmer for 20 years. He is 43 years old from Sto. Niño, Surallah. The previous harvest season has been good to him, and so he is looking forward to a better income this time around. 

He applied for a loan due to limited money at hand. He will use the money for fertilizer, seedlings and land preparation before the planting season. The additional income will go to his aging parents’ needs and his family’s daily needs.

loans.use: farm supplies such as fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred C. is 43 years old and is from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He is married and has two children aged 9 and 7.

To provide for his family, Fred has a farming business which he has been doing for twenty-two years to help his wife. The loan will be used for farming necessities like farming tools, fertilizers and the expense of land preparation.

Fred’s main goal is to have a higher income from this business so that he can reinvest his profit in other business opportunities. The additional income will go to his family's daily consumption and his children's education.

loans.use: To buy farming tools, fertilizers and to pay the expense of land preparation

loans.name: Gerlie

texts.en:
Gerlie B. is into farming to support his family. He and his family lives in Sto. Niño, a town in South Cotabato. He and his wife help each other in tilling the land, hoping for a good harvest.

Gerlie applied for a loan knowing that this could help them. The money will be use to acquire seed and fertilizer. They are expecting a better yield on their crops for having the means now to buy the needed farming maintenance.

Any income derived from this business will be spent on Gerlie’s family’s daily consumption and on future business investment.

loans.use: To acquire seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Jemlyn

texts.en:
Sto. Niño, a town in South Cotabato, is known for its farming businesses. 45-year-old Jemlyn D. is no different. He hails from this place and farming has been his way of generating income for his family. He is married with two daughters aged 18 and 16.

Jemlyn requested a loan so that he can buy his farming needs like seed and fertilizer. Business profitability is his main goal so he can support his children’s schooling. Any additional income will go to his family’s daily needs, to future savings and as a church donation.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Since 1981, Laurence has been into farming to support his family. He is from the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He is 49 years old and is married with four children aged 21, 19, 14 and 10.

With the money from the loan, Laurence plans to buy more farming tools and farming inputs like seed, fertilizer, and other items. Business profitability is his main goal so that he can send his children to school and give them a better future. The additional income will go to his family's daily consumption, to his children's education and to possible new business opportunities.

loans.use: To buy farm tools and inputs like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy B. lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Since she got married, she has run a farming business to help her husband support their family. She has seven children and the younger ones are still in school.

With the money from the loan, Mercy plans to purchase farming tools and farming inputs like seed and fertilizer. She also wants to use the money to finance the labor of the people who will be hired during the harvest season. The additional income will go to her children’s education and to the family's daily consumption.

loans.use: To buy farming tools and inputs like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Mobito

texts.en: Mobito N., who is the 50-year-old father of a 21-year-old, lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, where he earns a living through rice farming. With the money from his requested loan, Mobito intends to buy fertilizer, seeds and other farm inputs. He plans to work hard on his farm so he can eventually include vegetables. From this loan, he  expects a good harvest and an increase in business profitability, with the additional income going to his family's daily living requirements and possibly some new business opportunities.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Since 1995, farming, hog raising and fish farming have been Nenita G.’ sources of income in Sto. Niño. A 59-year-old mother of four grown children, Nenita never considers her age to be a hindrance to dreaming of a bigger business. Having applied for a loan of Php17,000 from CEVI, she plans to expand her business and buy farming necessities and more piglets to raise. The additional income will go to her family's daily consumption and savings for her future needs.

loans.use: To buy farming necessities and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy B., from the village of Calinaoan, is 37 years old, married, and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Mercy owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 1200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mercy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise, Mercy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has been practicing mixed farming for fifteen years in Murang'a town, central Kenya. His main products are milk and coffee which he sells at a local market. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same area.

James has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000KES to expand his poultry farm. He hopes that with this loan, he will be able to buy more chickens to increase his income. In the future, he hopes to acquire at least 1000 chickens to produce over 30 trays of eggs. His biggest challenge has been lack of sufficient funds to sustain the business due to the high cost of feed.

James is 47 years old. He is married with two children ages 8 and 12. Both children attend school.

He comments that farmers will be able to grow through the Juhudi projects which make financing available to small-scale farmers.

loans.use: To expand his poultry project

loans.name: Ivarat's Group

texts.en:
Ivarat A. is leader of the group. She is 57 and a widow. She has three children: her oldest son is 37, her second son is 35 and her daughter is 26. Her oldest son works in Russia, her second son works in Kazakhstan and her daughter is married and lives independently. She has farmed and bred cattle for almost 15 years. She started her business with an initial investment of 10,000 soms. She now earns 1,500 soms each month selling milk, breeding cattle and farming. She plans to use her profits to marry off her children and increase her herd of cattle. She is applying for a loan to purchase additional cattle for breeding. In the future, she plans to further increase her herd and build a big shed.
Group members:
Alymbiubiu O. is treasurer of the group. She is 60 years old and a widow. She has four children: her daughters are 36 and 31 and her sons are 33 and 30. Her daughters are married and live independently, her elder son works in Moscow and her youngest son lives with Alymbiubiu. She breeds cattle with the help of her son. She started cattle breeding four years ago with an initial investment of 4,000 soms. Now, she earns 1,500 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan to purchase additional cattle. In the future, she is planning to marry off her son with the help of the profits from cattle breeding. 
Kalbiubiu A. is 38 and married. She has six children: her daughters are 19, 18, 13, 11, and six and her son is two years old. Her oldest daughter works in Almaty (Kazakhstan), her next three daughters go to school and her youngest daughter and son are at home. Kalbiubiu sells five or six liters of milk and rolls. Kalbiubiu started selling milk from a purchase of cattle two years ago. She started with an initial investment of 3,000 soms and she now earns 1,500 soms each month. She is applying for a loan to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she plans to make repairs to her house and increase her cattle herd. 
Nazgul U. is 31 and married. She has two daughters who are four and three years old. Both of them are at home. She and her husband are farmers. They are preparing for the harvest. Her monthly income is 1,000 soms. She is applying for a loan to start cattle breeding. In the future, she hopes to use the profits to increase the herd and repair her house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Rocsan

texts.en:
Rocsan M. is from the village of Faustino, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 23 years old. Rocsan is married and has two infant children. Rocsan owns and operates a livestock business. The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. Rocsan is just starting this business.

In 2010, Rocsan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Rocsan is requesting a new loan of 4000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rocsan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Zherendi's Group

texts.en:
Zherendi K. is leader of this group. She is forty-seven and widow. She has three children: her daughter is twenty-six and her sons are twenty-seven and twenty-three years old. Her elder son is a construction worker and lives with his own family independently, her daughter is also married and lives independently, and her youngest son works in Kazakhstan.

She resells agricultural products and milk. Three years ago, she started her business with a purchase of agricultural products for 6,000 soms which she resold at a higher price.  She is applying for a loan to purchase wheat and barley for resale at a higher price. In the future, she is planning to expand her business.

Group members:

Asel I. is treasurer of the group. She is thirty-six and married. She has four children: her son is twelve and her daughters are eleven, four, and two years old. Her elder son and daughter go to school and her youngest two daughters are at home. Her husband is a carpenter. Her husband learned from his farther skills of making different things from wood. 

Asel breeds cattle and she sells nearly ten or twelve liters of milk a day. Together with her husband, she is in the business nearly eighteen years. They started with an initial investment of 1,000 soms. Now, they earn 4,000 soms each month. For now, they could purchase a car and build a house. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase wood for her husband. In the future, they are planning to expand their business and increase the size of their cattle herd. 

Chynarkul S. is fifty and married. She is tractor driver. She has five children: her sons are thirty, twenty-nine, twenty-two, and sixteen, and her daughter is nine years old. 

Her elder son is married. He works and lives independently in Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan) with his own family. Her second son works in Russia. Her third son works in Cholpon-Ata. Her youngest son and daughter go to school. She started cattle breeding fourteen years ago with initial investment of 2,500 soms. For now, she could increase significantly the number of cattle she owns and increase her earnings to 2,000 soms monthly. 

She is applying for a loan to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she is planning to increase the size of her cattle herd, marry her children and build a big house for her family. 

Sveta A. is thirty-six and married. She has five children: her youngest daughter is four months old; her other daughters are nine, thirteen, and sixteen years old; and her son is fifteen years old. Her elder children go to school and her youngest daughter is at home. 

She breeds cattle. Her children help her in cattle breeding. She started cattle breeding nine years ago with a purchase of cattle for 3,000 soms. She earns 1,500 soms from cattle breeding. She also sells five or six liters of milk a day. She could build a house and increase her cattle quantity with the help of her business. 

She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she is planning to continue increasing the size of her cattle herd and to purchase furniture for her house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line--People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan   Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase wheat and barley

loans.name: Burul's Group

texts.en:
Burul I. is the leader of this group. She is forty-five and married. She has three children: her two sons are twenty-five and twenty-three and her daughter is elven years old. Her sons are construction workers and her daughter goes to school. Her husband is a construction worker and he earns 7,000 soms monthly. She farms and breeds cattle with the help of her children. 

She started her business three years ago with initial investment of 14,000 soms. She has been able to increase the number of cattle she owns, purchase furniture, and increase her income to 3,000 soms monthly.  She is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle and increase her profits. In the future, she is planning to buy more cattle, a car, and a plot of land in Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan).

Group members:

Kanyshtyk S. is forty-seven and divorced. She has seven children: her sons are twenty-seven, twenty-six, twenty-three, and nineteen, and her daughters are twenty-five, twenty-two and eighteen years old. Her elder son is a construction worker in Bishkek, her second son is married and lives with his family in Kazakhstan, and her youngest son is a general worker and lives with Kanyshtyk. Her daughters are married and live with their families. 

She sells convenience goods. Six years ago, she decided to rent a small shop and purchased convenience goods for 1,000 soms. She has been able to increase her turnover and marry her sons and daughters. She is planning to expand her business. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional convenience goods for increasing her turnover. In the future, she is planning to expand her business and increase her turnover to 50,000 soms, marry her youngest son and purchase furniture. 

Nazgul Y. is thirty-six and married. She has three children: her sons are eight and one and her daughter is twelve years old. Her elder son and daughter go to school and her youngest son is at home. He husband resells agricultural products. 

Also, together with her husband, Nazgul is farming. She started ten years ago with initial investment of 2,000 soms following the suggestion of their relatives. Now, she earns 3,000 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase necessary things for farming. This Autumn, she is planning to sow garlic, build a shed and make repairs to her house. 

Damira I. is forty-three and married. She has two sons of twenty and three years old. Her elder son is a tractor driver and her youngest son is at home. Her husband is a merchant. She helps her husband in his business. They sell convenience goods and office and school accessories. 

They started five years ago by renting a place at the local market where they were selling convenience goods. Their initial investment was 15,000 soms. For now, they could increase their turnover and purchase household appliances and increase their income to 4,000 soms. 

She is applying for a loan in order to purchase goods for increasing their turnover. They are planning to purchase office and school accessories for new academic year and expect high returns. In the future, they are planning to open a shop, increase their turnover and purchase a car. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line--People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan   Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Nickie

texts.en: Nickie P. of Sto. Niño has had a farming and hog raising business since 2007. She has one son who is only 3 years old. This loan will be used to buy more piglets and their vitamins and supplements, as well as pig feed. Aside from these businesses, she plans to try other business opportunities someday to prepare for her child’s education. The additional income will go to her family's daily consumption and savings for future investments.

loans.use: buying piglets, vitamins, supplements, and pig feed

loans.name: Sovetkan's Group

texts.en:
Sovetkan H. is the leader of this group. She is forty-seven and a widow. She has five children: her daughters are twenty-seven, twenty-three, twenty-two, and twenty, and her son is seventeen years old. Her daughters are married and live independently, her elder son lives with Sovetkan and helps her, and her youngest son is studying religious studies in Turkey. 

With the help of her elder son, Sovetkan breeds cattle. She started two years ago with initial investment of 15,000 soms. She has been able to educate her children on the profits from cattle breeding and increase her income to 3,000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she is planning to increase her cattle herd further and make  repairs to her house.

Group members:

Ainur M. is the treasurer of the group. She is forty-six and married. She has three sons of twenty-two, nineteen, and seventeen years old. Her elder son graduated from medical college, her second son is a student in an  institution of higher education, and her youngest son is expected to graduate from high school this year. Her husband is a veterinarian. She breeds cattle and resells veterinary medicines.

They started fifteen years ago with the purchase of cattle for 15,000 soms. They have been able to educate their children, open a veterinary drug store, build a house, and increase their monthly income to 5,000 soms. In the near future, they are planning to buy more cattle, marry their son, and purchase household appliances. 

Sypaiy K. is forty-nine and married. She has three children: her sons are twenty-four and nineteen and her daughter is twenty-three years old. Her elder son is a merchant, her elder daughter is married and lives independently, and her youngest son is at home. 

She farms and breeds cattle and her son and husband help her. Also, she sells from eight to nine liters of milk each morning. They started fifteen years ago with a purchase of cattle for 6,000 soms. They have built a shed, purchased a house, educated their children, and increased their income to 2,000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle. It would increase her turnover and as a result, it would increase her profits. In the near future, she is planning to buy more cattle and purchase furniture.
 
Dinara U. is forty-six and married. She has five children: her daughters are twenty-two, sixteen, twelve and her sons are twenty and eight years old. Her elder daughter is married and lives independently, her elder son is a student at an institution of higher education, and all her other children go to school. 

She breeds cattle and her children actively help her. Also, she sells twenty liters of milk a day. She started cattle breeding three years ago with initial investment of 15,000 soms. With the profits from cattle breeding, she educated her son and increased her turnover. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the near future, she is planning to buy more cattle, marry her son, and purchase household appliances. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line--People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan   Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchasing cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Niel

texts.en:
47 year-old Niel G. from Sto. Niño earns a living through rice farming.  With rice being the staple food in the country, he has had his share of profits from his hard work from the previous harvest season.

With the money that he is requesting from this loan, he plans to buy sacks of fertilizers and seeds. He works hard on his farm so that he can expect a good harvest and increase his profits. The additional income generated will go to his family's daily consumption, future savings and possible new business opportunities.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Nieva

texts.en:
Nieva Agreda of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, has had a farming business since 2000. She has eight adult children with the youngest aged 23 years-old.   At the age of 65 years-old, she is still a hard working woman and she realizes that she needs to work hard especially since she is already a widow and her children have families of their own. 

The money from the loan will be used to buy fertilizers, seedlings and other farm materials. Her additional income will go to her savings for future needs especially health maintenance and to financially help her grandchildren.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seedlings and other farm materials.

loans.name: Pacifico

texts.en:
With his rice farming business and Tilapia (St. Peter fish) production, life has been good to Pacifico G.'s family. He is 54 years-old, married and has four children aged 22, 20, 19 and 17 years.  

However, in order to maximize his business profits, he wants to expand his business. To meet the needed capital requirement for his planned expansion, he has applied for a loan to buy farm materials and Tilapia feed. The additional income generated will be used for his children’s schooling and other possible business opportunities.

loans.use: To purchase farm materials and Tilapia feed.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice has a mixed farm in the town of Nkubu in eastern Kenya, where she has been farming for five years. Her farm produces maize and bananas which she sells to middlemen and milk which she sells through the Kigane Dairy Society. She mainly depends on the income from her farming to provide for her family.

Alice is 36 years-old. She is married with three children aged 12, 9 and 2½. Two of the children attend school.

Alice recently repaid her previous loan from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo of 35,000KES and has requested this loan of 70,000KES to purchase a dairy cow. She says that this loan will help her expand her farming by acquiring another quality dairy cow. The income from her farm will enable her to educate her children and improve the living standards of her family. Her biggest challenges have been unpredictable weather conditions, the high cost of farm inputs and lack of labour.

She plans to expand her farming by practising extensive maize, dairy and banana farming in future. She says that Juhudi has helped empower her economically.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph K., a 48-year-old single video show operator in Mikindani, Mombasa supports his two children and has been in this business ten years. His income has been great and now he is requesting his second loan from KADET to open another video show shop.  Joseph anticipates a boost in business after this investment and thus the profit will be used to invest in any other business field which he finds appropriate.  In the future he would like to sustain his family and see his business grow.

loans.use: To open another video show shop

loans.name: Pedrito

texts.en: Pedrito Crescencio, a 54-year-old married father of four children, is from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, where he supports his family through farming. Pedrito has great dreams for his children, the reason he works hard tilling his land. He is now requesting a loan to help purchase his farm inputs including seedlings, fertilizer and farm tools. The additional income accruing from the business will go to his children’s education, family consumption and savings for their future.

loans.use: To purchase seedlings, fertilizer and farm tools

loans.name: Reachel

texts.en: Reachel is a married, has one child and makes a living by running a beauty salon. She has been in this line of work for eight years, and now has one employee. She gets some financial assistance from her husband, and has also received a loan from the Mwangaza group in Faulu Kenya.  She says that this loan helped her improve her standard of living by allowing her to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to open two additional salons, but for now is applying for a new loan to buy equipment, including a hair drier, camera and beauty products such as nail polish, hair chemicals and hair braids. She describes herself as friendly and outgoing.

loans.use: To buy equipment for her beauty salon

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is a dairy farmer who lives in Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. For the last 16 years, he has made a living managing a farm and now employs two people. He generates income by selling milk and maize in the local market.

Samwel is 49 years old,  married and has five children who are between the ages of 5 and 18. All of his children currently attending school.

Samwel recently repaid his second loan from Juhudi Kilimo. Now he is applying for a third loan, for 70,000 KES, to buy a cow. He says that the extra income made possible by this loan will help him pay his children's school fees. His main challenge at the moment is securing enough feed for his animals.

He is grateful to Juhudi for the help it has provided.

loans.use: To buy a cow.
